action.name: Throw
entries: Using the {@action Attack} action, you can make a special maneuver to launch a willing creature. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this attack replaces one of them. The target of you throw must be your size or smaller, and it must be within reach of your unarmed strikes. A creature that is smaller than you can be thrown a number of feet equal to your Strength score, or half as far for a creature that is your size. A creature begins falling at the end of this movement if it is still aloft.

entries.name: Optional: Throwing Unwilling Creatures
entries: At the DM's discretion, you may attempt to throw an unwilling creature you have {@condition grappled}, that is your size or smaller. You make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (the target chooses the ability to use). You succeed automatically if the target is incapacitated. If you succeed, the target is thrown as decribed above.

items: The creature and its equipment weigh one eighth as much as normal. Items gain or lose this effect when the creature picks up or drops them respectively.
The creature counts as one size smaller for the purpose of mounting other creatures or being moved by spells, effects and other creatures.

When the creature falls, it takes {@dice 1d4} bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it falls rather than {@dice 1d6}. Alternatively, if you are using the {@variantrule variant fall damage|J:General} rules, the creature counts as one size smaller for the purpose of calculating damage from falling.
If the creature gains the {@condition weighted|J:General} condition, both conditions cancel each other out and the creature is treated as having neither until one is removed.
The creature and its equipment weigh eight times as much as normal. Items gain or lose this effect when the creature picks up or drops them respectively.
The creature counts as one size larger for the purpose of mounting other creatures or being moved by spells, effects and other creatures.

When the creature falls, it takes {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it falls rather than {@dice 1d6}. Alternatively, if you are using the {@variantrule variant fall damage|J:General} rules, the creature counts as one size larger for the purpose of calculating damage from falling.
If the creature gains the {@condition lightened|J:General} condition, both conditions cancel each other out and the creature is treated as having neither until one is removed.

condition.name: Sundered
entries: A sundered creature's Armor Class cannot benefit from nonmagical armor or shields. If the armor would limit a creature's ability to add its Dexterity modifier to its Armor Class or impose disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks, it still does. For example, a creature with a Dexterity modifer of +3 that is wearing {@item scale mail|phb}, their AC becomes 12.

entries.name: Non-Standard Armor Class
entries: If the target uses a non-standard method for calculating its Armor Class, such as a flat value, the DM decides how this affects it. They might choose armor that is equivalent to what the target is actually using, they might choose to apply a -2 penalty, or they might decide the target would be unaffected and apply no penalty.

items: A staggered creature's Armor Class cannot include its Dexterity Modifier (unless it is negative).
A staggered creature has disadvantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws.

entries.name: Non-Standard Armor Class
entries: If the target uses a non-standard method for calculating its Armor Class, such as a flat value, the DM decides how this affects it. They might choose armor that is equivalent to what the target is actually using, they might choose to apply a -2 penalty, or they might decide the target would be unaffected and apply no penalty.

items: A distracted creature has disadvantage on Intelligence and Wisdom checks.
A distracted creature has disadvantage on saving throws made to maintain concentration on a spell.
A distracted creature has disadvantage on initiative.
A taunted creature has disadvantage on attack rolls against targets other than the one that taunted it. If the the creature is taunted by multiple targets it has disadvantage against all of them.

entries.name: Using this condition in game
entries: Some spells and effects within the game already impose similar effects, such as the Compelled Duel spell. The DM is free to replace such effects with this condition.

The DM is also free to grant certain creature special traits relating to the condition as they deem appropriate. For example, a creature may have advantage or disadvantage on saving throws against it, or even be immune to the condition

items: A silenced creature cannot speak or cast spells with verbal components.

entries.name: Using this condition in game
entries: Some spells and effects within the game already impose similar effects, such as the Silence spell. The DM is free to replace such effects with this condition.

The DM is also free to grant certain creature special traits relating to the condition as they deem appropriate. For example, a creature may have advantage or disadvantage on saving throws against it, or even be immune to the condition

items: A hampered creature has its speed reduced by 10 feet. Sometimes an effect may only hamper certain speeds, otherwise the condition reduces all speeds
This condition can be imposed multiple times simultaneously, combining the reduction, but only once from each source.

entries.name: Using this condition in game
entries: Some spells and effects within the game already impose similar effects, such as the Lance of Lethergy invocation. The DM is free to replace such effects with this condition.

The DM is also free to grant certain creature special traits relating to the condition as they deem appropriate. For example, a creature may have advantage or disadvantage on saving throws against it, might increase or decrease the reduction to 5 feet, or even be immune to the condition

items: A slowed creature's speed is halved.

entries.name: Using this condition in game
entries: Some spells and effects within the game already impose similar effects, such as the Slow spell. The DM is free to replace such effects with this condition.

The DM is also free to grant certain creature special traits relating to the condition as they deem appropriate. For example, a creature may have advantage or disadvantage on saving throws against it, might instead gain the {@condition hampered|J:general} condition, or even be immune to the condition

condition.name: Lingering
entries: The creature has sustained some injury or effect that deals damage over time. When the condition is imposed, associated damage is defined, such as Lingering (3 Slashing) or Lingering (PB Necrotic).

items: At the start of each of its turns, the creature takes the associated damage described in parentheses. If the associated damage uses PB, it refers to the Proficiency Bonus of the creature that imposed the condition. If that creature's Proficiency Bonus changes, such as with the {@spell Polymorph|XPHB} spell, this condition continues to use the bonus at the time the condition was imposed.

condition.name: Bleeding
entries: The creature has sustained an injury or similar effect that is causing them to lose a lot of blood or ichor. The DM might decide that a creature that does not rely on blood or ichor, such as an undead, a construct or an incorporeal elemental, is immune to this condition.

items: The creature has the {@condition Lingering|J:general|Lingering (PB Slashing)} condition.
The creature has disadvantage on Constitution saving throws.
The condition can be removed with a Wisdom (Medicine) check (DC 10 + the imposing creature's Proficiency Bonus), by using a {@item healer's kit|phb} or by magical healing.
A cramped creature has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls that rely on the use of its arms, hands or similar appendages, such as claws or talons.
A cramped creature cannot cast spells with somatic or material components, even if they use a spellcasting focus to replace these components.

On a dazed creature's turn it must choose between taking an action, a bonus action or moving, it gets one of the three. If it gets additional actions from another source, such as the {@spell haste|XPHB} spell, it can still take these as normal.

If a creature becomes dazed on its turn, the condition takes effect immediately, taking into account any actions, bonus actions and movement it has already taken this turn. If it already began one of these before gaining the condition, it can complete it before ending its turn.
The condition can be removed with a {@spell lesser restoration|XPHB} spell or similar.

condition.name: Flanked
entries: If your game uses the optional {@variantrule flanking|DMG} rules, the DM may decide that certain creatures are immune to flanking and attackers do not gain advantage on attack rolls against due to flanking. Such creatures may gain this immunity to having multiple heads, many limbs, many eyes, keen spatial awareness or who cannot be distracted, such as hydras, mariliths, beholders, monks, modrons or other creatures at the DM's discretion.

condition.name: Berserk
entries: The creature has been pushed into an irrational fury or paranoia, wanting to lash out at all around them. Restraining themselves is painfully difficult. When the condition is imposed, associated damage amount is defined, such as Berserk (5) or Berserk (PB).

items: The creature is hostile to all other creatures and has advantage on saving throws against the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition.
If the creature is also {@condition Taunted|J:General}, it cannot willingly move away from the taunter.

At the end of each of its turns, if the creature has not dealt damage to a creature other than itself since the end of its last turn (not counting damage inflicted via the {@condition Lingering|J:General} condition), it takes psychic damage equal to the amount described in parentheses. If the associated damage uses PB, it refers to the Proficiency Bonus of the creature that imposed the condition. If that creature's Proficiency Bonus changes, such as with the {@spell Polymorph|XPHB} spell, this condition continues to use the bonus at the time the condition was imposed.
This condition can be removed with the {@spell Calm Emotions|XPHB} or {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} spells or similar.

feat.name: Tinkerer
entries: You are a talented craftsman, able to create contraptions beyond common understanding, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Tinker's Talents
entries: You gain proficiency with {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB} if you don't already have it. Additionally, you can use Tinker's Tools as a spellcasting focus.

entries.name: Memorised Designs
entries: You learn 2 plans from {@table Magic Item Plans (Artificer Level 2+)|XUA2025EberronUpdates} table (these are added to any existing plans you know from any other source). Whenever you gain a level, you can change one of these plans for a another one from the same table.

entries.name: Replicate Design
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can create a magic item using one of the plans you know. If a created item requires {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB}, you can attune yourself to it the instant you create it. If you decide to attune to the item later, you must do so using the normal process for {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB}.
The item lasts until you die or you create another item this way, after which the item vanishes.

feat.name: Hoplite
entries: You adopt the fighting style of the hoplite, with spear and shield in hand. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Superior Spear Style
entries: When using a {@item Spear|XPHB}, {@item Bident|J:General} or {@item Trident|XPHB} in one hand and a {@item Shield|XPHB} in the other, you can benefit from the Versatile property as if you were wielding the weapon with 2 hands.

entries.name: Far Throw
entries: Attacking at long range does not impose {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on your ranged attack rolls when using {@item Spear|XPHB|Spears}, {@item Bident|J:General|Bidents}, {@item Trident|XPHB|Tridents} or {@item Javelin|XPHB|Javelins}.

entries.name: Shield Wall
entries: While you are within 5 feet of a friendly creature and both of you are wielding {@item Shield|XPHB|Shields}, you each gain a +1 bonus to your Armor Class. A creature can gain this benefit only once, even if multiple adjacent creatures have this feat (or the SHield Wall trait).

feat.name: Pit Fighter
entries: You have adopted a flashly fighting style that always goes down well with the arena crowds. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Style over Substance
entries: When you make a weapon attack against a creature, and at least one other creature can see both of you, you can add your Charisma modifer to the attack and damage rolls (doubling it if you already do). If this attack reduces a creature to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, you perform a dramatic finisher and gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

feat.name: Blood Mage Initiate
entries: You can harness the power of your own vitality to enhance your spells. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Blood for Power
entries: When you cast a spell that restores {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or deals damage to creature other than you, you can roll a number of d4s up to your Proficiency Bonus and deal additional damage or healing to one target of the spell. You then take take necrotic damage equal to half the number rolled (minimum of 1), which can't be reduced in any way.

entries.name: Sacrifice
entries: As an {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can recover an expended spell slot. Your maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} are reduced by an amount equal to five times the level of the spell slot recovered until the end of your next {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

feat.name: Throwing Weapon Master
entries: You have mastered the art of throwing weapons. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Slinging Savant
entries: Melee weapons you are proficient with, and that lack the Two-Handed property, have the Thrown property while you wield them.

entries.name: Far Throw
entries: Attacking at long range does not impose {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on your ranged attack rolls when using a weapon that has the Thrown property.

entries.name: Close Throw
entries: Being within 5 feet of an enemy does not impose {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on your ranged attack rolls.

feat.name: Whipmaster
entries: You have mastered the art of using whips. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Whip Affinity
entries: When you wield a {@item Whip|XPHB}, its damage die changes from a {@dice d4} to a {@dice d6}. Additionally, Whips have the Light property while you wield them.

entries.name: Grasping Whip
entries: When you hit a creature with an attack using a {@item Whip|XPHB}, you can force the target to make a Strength saving throw (DC 8 plus the ability modifier used to make the attack roll and your Proficiency Bonus). On a fail, the target is knocked {@condition Prone|XPHB} or pulled 5 feet towards you (your choice).

feat.name: Angelic Healer
entries: The divine energy within you has grown stronger. You gain the following benefits:

items: You can use your Healing Hands trait as either a bonus action or an action.
You can use your Healing Hands trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all uses upon finishing a long rest.
When you use an action to heal a creature with your Healing Hands trait, the creature regains an additional {@dice 2d4} hitpoints.

feat.name: Angelic Revelation
entries: The divine energy within you has grown stronger. You gain the following benefits:

items: You can use your Celestial Revelation trait again after finishing a short or long rest. In addtion, when you finish a short or long rest, you can change your Celestial Revelation for a different one.

When you use the Necrotic Shroud or Radiant Consumption revelation, the range is 15ft, rather than 10ft. In addition, when you use the Radiant Soul revelation, your speed is increased by 10ft for the duration of your transformation.

When you, or a creature you can see within 5ft is targeted by an attack roll and you are using your Celestial Revelation trait, you can use a reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll as you obscure the targeted creature with your light or wings.

entries: {@note This feat was designed for use with the {@race aasimar|mpmm} race from Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse. It may require adjustment to work with older versions of the race.}

feat.name: Magic Initiate (Variant)
entries: You learn {@filter two cantrips|spells|level=0} and {@filter one 1st-level spell of your choice|spells|level=1}. You can cast the chosen 1st-level spell without a spell slot, and you must finish a long rest before you can cast it in this way again. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.
Your spellcasting ability for this feat's spells is Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma (choose when you select this feat).

feat.name: Chef (Revised)
entries: Time spent mastering the culinary arts has paid off, granting you the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency with {@item cook's utensils|phb} if you don't already have it. If you have the Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature, you can also use these tools as a spellcasting focus.

When you use Cook's Utensils to prepare meals during a short rest, creatures of your choice regain additional hit points equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded up) per Hit Die spent rather than 1. In addition, each creature that consumes the food gains temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

You can use various kitchen implements as simple weapons or shields, as agreed with your DM. For example, you might use a rolling pin as a {@item club|phb}, a cleaver as a {@item handaxe|phb} or a frying pan as a {@item shield|phb}.

feat.name: Actor (Revised)
entries: Skilled at mimicry and dramatics, you gain the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Deception}) and Charisma ({@skill Performance}) checks when trying to pass yourself off as a different person.

You can mimic the speech of another person or the sounds made by other creatures. You must have heard the person speaking, or heard the creature make the sound, for at least 1 minute. A successful Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check contested by your Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check allows a listener to determine that the effect is faked.

You can attempt to {@action Hide} in a crowded area, such as a markeplace or tavern. When you do so, you can choose to make a Charisma (Deception or Stealth) check in place of Dexterity (Stealth). As normal, you cannot hide from a creature if it can clearly see you, however, once you are hidden, being visible does not necessarily reveal your location so long as you act as part of the normal crowd.

feat.name: Mask of Mist
entries: You hone your skills with masks and gain the following benefits:

items.name: Marvelous Mask
entries: At the end of a short or long rest rest, you can condense some of your vaporous essence into a special mask, which lasts until it is destroyed or you use this feat to make another one. The mask has an appearance of your choice, though it is obviously a mask, typically an imitation of a humanoid face made from ceramic, metal or glass. The mask is fully animated and can simulate the full range of facial expressions availble to the type of humanoid the mask most resembles.

As an action or bonus action, you can remove the mask and allow it to move independently on your turn. You can don the mask again with a subsequent action or bonus action. While separated from you in this way, the mask is an object with 15 AC, 10 hit points, a flying speed of 20 feet and it can hover. While the mask is within 120 feet of you, you can telepathically command it to move (no action required).

While separated, you can use an action you view the world through the mask's eyes, hear through its space and speak through it until the start of your next turn. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.

feat.name: Combustable Trails
entries: The smoke and mist that forms you is slighlty flamable, it takes a lot to keep it under control, however, this volitility can be used to your advantage. You gain the following benefits:

items.name: Reactive Ignition
entries: You can use your Reactive Reformation trait when you take fire or lightning damage. When you do so, you can use the same reaction to deal fire damage equal to twice your Proficiency Bonus to an object or creature of your choice within 10 feet of you. A flamable object hit by this ignites if it isn't being worn or carried.

feat.name: Agile Fighting
entries: All melee weapons that lack the heavy, two-handed or special properties gain the finesse property when you wield them.

feat.name: Akimbo Shooting
entries: You can engage in two-weapon fighting even if one or both weapons are ranged. In addition, you do not need a hand free to load ammunition into ranged weapons (you still require two hands to use weapons with the two-handed property).

feat.name: Prone Fighting
entries: Being {@condition prone|xphb} does not impose disadvantage on your weapon attack rolls.

feat.name: Wargamer
entries: You gain the following benefits.

items.name: Hobbyist
entries: You gain proficiency with {@item Painter's Supplies|XPHB} and {@item Wargaming Set|J:General|Wargaming Sets} if you don't already have them.

items.name: Painted Armies
entries: When you finish a Long Rest, with {@item Painter's Supplies|XPHB} and a {@item Wargaming Set|J:General} in hand, you can improve the Wargaming Set by painting the armies in it. When you do so, the value of the set increases by 10gp and grants you a +1 bonus to ability checks made using it.

items.name: Scale Models of War
entries: When you finish a Long Rest, with a {@item Wargaming Set|J:General} in hand, you can play games in preparation for upcoming battles. When you do so, choose up to six creatures of your choice who participate in or witness the games (which can include yourself). The chosen creatures gain a bonus to initiative rolls and the first attack roll they make in the first round of combat. This bonus is equal to the modifier of the ability you increased with this feat and lasts until a creature finishes their next Long Rest.

feat.name: Trap Master
entries: Even the simplest items can become brutally effective in your hands. You gain the following benefits.

items.name: Cunning Contraptions
entries: You gain special benefits with the following items; {@item Alchemist's Fire|XPHB}, {@item Ball Bearings|XPHB}, {@item Bell|XPHB}, {@item Caltrops|XPHB}, {@item Chain|XPHB}, {@item Hunting Trap|XPHB}, {@item Holy Water|XPHB}, {@item Iron Spikes|XPHB}, {@item Lock|XPHB}, {@item Manacles|XPHB}, {@item Net|XPHB}, {@item Oil|XPHB}, {@item Rope|XPHB}, {@item Signal Whistle|XPHB} and {@item String|XPHB}. The DM might allow additional {@filter Adventuring Gear|items|type=adventuring gear}.

items: You can craft the item for half the usual time and cost.
If the item requires a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action or replaces an attack you make as part of the {@action Attack} action, you use the item as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.
If the item allows a creature to make a saving throw, the DC equals 8 plus your Proficiency Bonus plus the modifier of the ability you increased with this feat, if it is not already higher.

items.name: Multiplex Machine
entries: You know the {@spell Snare|XGE} spell and can cast it once without a spell slot, regaining the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a Long Rest. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have. Your spellcasting ability for this spell is the one you increased with this feat.

item.name: Necklace of Beards
entries: While wearing this necklace a creature's beard grows by half an inch after each long rest, even if they could not normally grow a beard.

item.name: Ring of Theatrics
entries: While wearing this ring, you can cast {@spell thaumaturgy|phb} as an action.

item.name: Ring of Tricks
entries: While wearing this ring, you can cast {@spell prestidigitation|phb} as an action.

item.name: Gloves of the Gardener
entries: While wearing these gloves, you can cast {@spell druidcraft|phb} as an action.

item.name: Shield Strap
entries: This leather strap can be used to hang a {@item shield|phb} from your shoulder. When using it in this manner, you may don or doff the shield as a bonus action rather than an action.

item.name: Buckler
entries: This small shield is made from wood or metal and is strapped to the forearm, leaving the hand free. Wielding a buckler increases your Armor Class by 1. You can benefit from only one shield or buckler at a time. You cannot use weapons with the two handed property while wielding this buckler.

item.name: Boots of Dramatic Hovering
entries: These boots allow you to hover dramatically up to 1 foot above the ground as a bonus action. Whilst hovering, you move as if you were walking. The boots do not grant you a flying speed or any protection from terrain, falls or traps.

item.name: Scroll of Unique Wish
entries: This scroll allows a creature to cast the {@spell wish|phb} spell. In addition to the usual drawbacks of the spell, if the creature's wish has ever been wished before, the wish fails and instead summons an {@creature avatar of death|dmg} that is hostile to the creature. The Dungeon Master decides if the wish is unique. Whether the wish suceeds or fails, the scroll burns up and can't be used again.

item.name: Temporal Gearbox
entries: This set of incrementally larger gears connected to a crank can be used to imprison a creature in a slower timestream. As an action you can point this device at a creature and turn the crank, forcing the creature to make a DC12 Wisdom saving throw. On a fail, the creature's perception of time is slowed to the speed where a single heartbeat takes a year (one round in combat takes 6 years).

The creature can act normally but only at their usual speed, even a quick action such as blinking can appear to take weeks or even months. For this reason, this device is commonly used as a torture device. The Dungeon Master decides how this experience affects the creature; rolling for one or more {@variantrule Madness|dmg} effects would be appropriate.

On subsequent turns, you can use an action to continue turning the crank, keeping the effect going. Otherwise, the effect lasts until the start of your next turn. At the end of each of it's turns, the creature can attempt to make the wisdom saving throw again, breaking free on a success. Once a creature has succeeded on a saving throw, it cannot be affected by this item again for 7 days.

item.name: Anti-Magic Collar
entries: This silver collar can be clasped onto a creature that has a neck and is {@condition incapacitated} as an action. While the clasp is shut, the creature cannot cast any spells.

The collar cannot be removed by changing size or shape, such as with the {@spell polymorph|phb} spell. Provided it has two hands free to do so, the creature can use an action on each of its turns to make a DC 15 Strength check. On a success, the collar is broken and becomes non-magical. On a fail, the creature gains a level of exhaustion and the collar remains.

item.name: Cruel Anti-Magic Collar
entries: This special {@item Anti-Magic Collar|J:General} can be clasped onto a creature that has a neck and is {@condition incapacitated} as an action. While the clasp is shut, the creature cannot cast any spells. If it attempts to do so, it takes {@dice 1d6} lightning damage per level of the spell ({@dice 1d6} for cantrips).

The collar cannot be removed by changing size or shape, such as with the {@spell polymorph|phb} spell. Provided it has two hands free to do so, the creature can use an action on each of its turns to make a DC 18 Strength check. On a success, the collar is broken and becomes non-magical. On a fail, the creature gains a level of exhaustion and the collar remains.

item.name: Shield of Bouncing
entries: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
In additon to a simple melee weapon, this weapon can be used as a {@item Shield|XPHB}, granting a +2 bonus to your armor class if you are wielding no other Shield.
Additionally, when you make a ranged attack using this weapon, the weapon bounces back to your hand after the attack.

item.name: Chronicles of Alvergia
entries: This heavy tome is part of a 12 volume compendium written by Annaleus of Rubin and contains information about the geography, politics, cultures, wildlife, theologies and cultures of the regions within Alvergia. Most versions are written in either common or elvish but versions can exist in most written languages. Each volume is worth about 25gp and covers a specific region in Alvergia, but the entire collection as a set is worth about 1000gp.

When you possess a volume of the book you may ask the DM for a piece of lore relating to the volume's respective region and they may give you some tidbits. For example, you could ask for details regarding a particular god or about the laws and customs of a city. The information should be something that a well researched scholar would know and deem worthy to mention. The DM may decide that a topic is too specific, insignificant or secret to appear in the volumes. They may also decide that a topic is broad enough to require several hours, or even days, of reading to fully understand it.
Below are the regions covered by each volume.

rows: Vol. I
The Sea of Cyranos
Vol. II
Enereon and Brindsmarch
Vol. III
The Evandrin Isles
Vol. IV
Ilahli
Vol. V
The Northlands
Vol. VI
Solis
Vol. VII
The Empire of Telnyr
Vol. VIII
The Pelais Coast and the Feywild
Vol. IX
The Plains of Vorkyr
Vol. X
The Dunes of Xheros
Vol. XI
Xia and the Forest of Muhai
Vol. XII
The Oceans and Lonely Islands

item.name: Tome of Many Cheeses
entries: This slightly damp catalogue of different types of cheeses has a funny smell. As an action, you can choose one of the cheeses listed and summon up to 5lbs of that type of cheese in a space adjacent to you. The cheese disappears if it is not consumed within 24 hours. Once you summon cheese, you cannot do so again until the next dawn.
In addition, whenever you find a new form of non-magical cheese, you can spend 10 minutes describing it on a new page in the book. It can then be summoned using the book.

item.name: Assassin's Teapot
entries: This specially designed teapot features two separate compartments that can hold different liquids, such as tea and poison. It also features a pair of secret holes on the handle, with which you to control which liquid is poured by covering specific holes. When you pour from this teapot, choose one or both of the liquids to be poured.
You have advantage on Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) checks made to avoid creatures noticing anything usual about the way you pour the teapot.

item.name: Hydra Blood
entries: This poison must be harvested from a dead or {@condition incapacitated|phb} {@creature hydra|mm}. You can use the poison in this vial to coat one slashing or piercing weapon or up to three pieces of ammunition. Applying the poison takes an action. A creature hit by the poisoned weapon or ammunition must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take {@dice 4d6} poison damage. Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying.

item.name: Cloak of Endless Poultry
entries: This feathered cloak holds some form of gateway to a demi plane full of chickens. The cloak has 5 charges, it regains {@dice 1d6-1} charges daily at dawn.

As an action you can expend a charge and open the cloak and {@dice 1d4} {@creature chicken|J:General|chickens} fall out into adjacent spaces. The chickens are friendly to you and your allies, they will follow you and may attack any creatures or objects that attack you but are otherwise unable to understand any commands you make. The chickens last for 1 hour or until they die, after which they either enter the cloak again or disappear in a puff of feathers.

item.name: Nautical Bone Charm
entries: This broken bone is inscribed with arcane runes and has 5 charges. It regains {@dice 1d4+1} charges daily at dawn.

As an action, you can expend a number of charges to cast the {@spell Spectral Crew|J:General} spell. For 1 charge, you cast the 2nd-level version of the spell. You can increase the spell slot level by one for each additional charge you expend.

item.name: +1 Pugilist Bracers
entries: While wearing these leather bracers, you have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with unarmed strikes.
In addition, your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

item.name: +2 Pugilist Bracers
entries: While wearing these leather bracers, you have a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with unarmed strikes.
In addition, your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

item.name: +3 Pugilist Bracers
entries: While wearing these leather bracers, you have a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with unarmed strikes.
In addition, your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

item.name: Bottle of Delights
entries: This clear, glass bottle can hold up to a gallon of liquid. When there is liquid in the bottle, you may cast {@spell Bazoz's Spicy Water|J:General} on the liquid at will.
If you pour the liquid out of the bottle, the effects remain active in the liquid for 1 hour, or until you use the bottle to cast the cantrip again.

item.name: Brine Poison
entries: This poison is harvested from brine pools deep underwater, the extreme salinity is toxic to most creatures. You can use the poison in this vial to coat one slashing or piercing weapon or up to three pieces of ammunition. Applying the poison takes an action. A creature hit by the poisoned weapon or ammunition must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take {@dice 2d4} poison damage and become {@condition incapacitated|phb} until the end of its next turn. Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying.
At the DM's discretion, if a creature is not acclimated to high salinity environments, they have disadvantge on the saving throw and take double the poison damage on a fail.

item.name: Silent Hammer
entries: This small, metal hammer produces no noise when used to strike something. The object or creature struck with the hammer also produces no noise as a result of the striking.

item.name: Magic Eyeliner
entries: This eyeliner is imbued with magic powders that grant the wearer benefits for a short duration. As an action, you can apply the eyeliner to a creature. That creature has truesight out to 60ft for the next 8 hours, after which the eyeliner ceases to be magical.

item.name: Ring of False Death
entries: This dark metal ring is popular with spies and criminals. When you take damage, you can use a reaction to cast the {@spell feign death|phb} spell on yourself without providing material components. Once you do so, you can not do so again until the next dawn.

item.name: Body Modder's Tools
additionalEntries: Proficiency with body modder's tools represents your ability to safely modify a creature's body with grafts, implants, piercings, scarification and tattoos. You also acquire an understanding of the history and symbolism of body modifications, which can aid you in producing and examining them.

additionalEntries.name: Components
entries: This kit includes needles, syringes, scalpels, gauze and small bottles of various dyes, inks, disinfectants and other chemicals.

additionalEntries.name: Arcana
entries: You gain additional insight when identifying the materials and patterns used in magic tattoos and other modifications.

additionalEntries.name: History and Religion
entries: You have greater understanding of the cultural and religious significance of certain body modifications.

additionalEntries.name: Medicine
entries: You can recognise and treat infections caused by unclean punctures and wounds. You also have better chances of spotting when a creature's appearance has been nonmagically modified, such as implanted horns or dyed skin.

additionalEntries.name: Modify
entries: As part of a long rest, you can expend at least 10gp worth of materials to perform (or reverse) a body modification on a willing creature, such as a tattoo or piercing. The DM may decide that more complex modifications require more valuable materials.

additionalEntries.caption: Body Modder's Tools
rows: Dye, tattoo or scar a creature's fur or skin.
Give a creature a piercing.
Graft or implant horns, scales, spikes, a tail or other decorative body parts.
Slightly alter the shape of a humanoid's facial features.
Make a humanoid appear as a different but similar race, or as a different sex.

additionalEntries.name: Scribing Magic Tattoos
entries: At the DM's discretion, proficiency with both body modder's tools and the arcana skill might allow a creature to scribe spellwrought tattoos in the same manner as they might scribe spell scrolls. In addition, they might also be able to convert a spell scroll into a spellwrought tattoo with an hour of work.
Finally, if the creature is a wizard, the DM might allow them to use their own skin as a spellbook, copying spells onto it as they would with a spellbook.

entries: Wisdom

item.name: Crude Prosthetic Limb
entries: This wood, metal or ceramic prosthetic replaces a lost limba hand, an arm, a foot, a leg, or a similar body part. While the prosthetic is attached, it functions almost identically to the part it replaces, however, its it clearly artificial and you have disadvantage on ability checks dependant on the limb. You can detach or reattach it as an action, and it can't be removed against your will unless you are incapcitated or dead.

item.name: Cosmetic Appendage
entries: This carefully crafted item resembles some natural appendage, such as horns, ears, a tail, a finger or similar body part. With {@item Body Modder's Tools|J:General} in hand, this item can be grafted or implanted onto, or removed from, a willing creature over the course of an hour to modify their appearance. The item is inert and purely cosmetic but otherwise appears natural.

item.name: Ring of Folding
entries: This segmented, metal ring has a surprisingly large interior compartment and can be used to hide weapons.
Over the course of 10 minutes, you can magically fold and store a single weapon inside the ring. You can then use a bonus action to unfold the wepon and summon it to your empty hand.

item.name: Voltaic Ball Bearings (bag of 1,000)
entries: As an action, you can spill these tiny metal balls from their pouch to cover a level area 10 feet square. A creature moving across the covered area must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone}. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the saving throw. If a creature in the area takes lightning damage, they take an additional {@dice 1d12} lightning damage.
Additionally, while holding the bag, you can use a bonus action to command any balls within 15ft to magically fly back into the bag via the most direct route.

entries.name: Curse
entries: This item is cursed. Attuning to it curses you until you are targeted by a spell such as {@spell remove curse} or a similar effect. While cursed, you are filled with an overwhelming urge to put one or more of the ball bearings in your mouth. While you do not have any ball bearings in your mouth, you have disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls and saving throws. While you have at least one ball bearing in your mouth, you are vulnerable to lightning damage. You are unwilling to part with all of the balls until the curse is broken with remove curse or similar magic, keeping at least one ball on your person at all times.

item.name: Gauntlets of the Hurricane
entries: These leather and iron scale gauntlets grant the wielder remarkable strength and control with melee weapons. This item has 3 charges, and regains {@dice 1d3} charges daily at dawn.
While attuned, you can use a bonus action to expend one charge and gain the following benefits for the next 10 minutes:

items: You can ignore the heavy property and any Strength requirements on melee weapons.
You can wield a melee weapon in one hand as if you were wielding it with two hands.
You can use two-weapon fighting even when the melee weapons you are wielding aren't light or one-handed. You can also add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

item.name: Ki Stone
entries: This jade stone bears a carving resembling a key on one side and one resembling a lock on the other. As an action, you can use this stone to expend 3 Ki points to cast either the {@spell arcane lock|phb} or {@spell knock|phb} spell. You must still provide any material components.

item.name: Ki Focusing Ring
item.reqAttune: by a monk with the spellcasting or pact magic feature
entries: This bimetallic, two-finger ring allows you to focus your Ki into magical reserves, or do the reverse. While attuned, you can use an action and spend 2 or more Ki points to recover an expended spell slot of a level equal to half the number of Ki points expended (rounded up). The recovered spell slot cannot be higher than 5th-level.
Alternatively, you can use an action and expend a spell slot to recover a number of expended Ki points equal to the level of the spell slot expended.

item.name: Boots of Explosive Propulsion
entries: These scorched leather and metal boots grant you extraordinary movement capabilities. This item has 3 charges, and regains {@dice 1d4} charges daily at dawn.

As a bonus action, you can expend a charge and cast the {@spell explosive propulsion|J:General} (save DC 15) spell on yourself, you do not provide material components for this casting. In addition, the spell does not require concentration and lasts for the full duration, or until you end the effect (no action required).

item.name: Spectacles of Glinting
entries: While wearing these spectacles, you can use a bonus action to make them glint stylishly. Some variants of this item may feature tinted glass.

item.name: Pocketplane Locket
entries: This locket contains a small demiplane in which constructs can live. This demiplane can be designed in any way the creator sees fit but can only hold up to six constructs and must be less than 1 mile in any dimension.

As an action you can touch a willing construct and place them inside the demiplane. While inside the locket, a construct's hitpoints cannot be changed and any conditions and effects are halted until the construct leaves the gem. The constructs are aware of the outside world but cannot communicate with any creatures outside.
As an action you can command any number of willing constructs to leave the gem and enter whatever plane the locket is on. They appear in an empty space within 10ft of the locket.

item.name: Potion of the Berserker
entries: This foul concoction is made of mushrooms and other psychoactive herbs, and can make creatures much more aggressive and reckless than they would normally be. When you drink this potion, you gain advantage on melee weapon attacks for 1 minute. Attack rolls against you have advantage for this duration.

item.name: Axe of Felling
entries: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, attacks with this weapon deal double damage against plants and objects made of wood.

This weapon has 3 charges, and it regains {@dice 1d3} expended charges daily at dawn. When you hit a creature with a melee attack using this weapon, you can use a bonus action to expend 1 charge and force the creature to make a DC 15 Charisma saving throw. On a fail, the creature is subjected to the effects of the {@spell timber|J:General} spell. You decide direction of the cone (originating from the target) and the space that the creature reappears in when the spell ends.

item.name: Belt of Swagger
entries: While wearing this fashionable belt, you instinctively walk with a cool and confident stride.

item.name: Tool Manual
entries: This tome contains the knowledge and instructions required to learn a particular tool, instrument or gaming set. With the associated tool in hand, you can spend up to 4 hours a day (which can done as light activity during Short or Long Rests) studying the book's contents. Once you have studied for a total of 24 hours, you can make a {@dc 10} Intelligence check. On a success, you gain Proficiency with the associated tool. On a fail, you must spend a further 12 hours studying the book to attempt the check again.

item.name: Expert Tool Manual
entries: This tome contains the knowledge and instructions required to master a particular tool, instrument or gaming set. With Proficiency in the associated tool and the tool itself in hand, you can spend up to 4 hours a day (which can done as light activity during Short or Long Rests) studying the book's contents. Once you have studied for a total of 72 hours, you can make a {@dc 20} Intelligence check. On a success, you gain Expertise with the associated tool. On a fail, you must spend a further 12 hours studying the book to attempt the check again.

item.name: Robe of the Desert
entries: This lightweight beige or tan robe can be worn with light or medium armor. The loose cloth around the shoulders can be formed into a simple hood and face mask, protecting the wearer from the elements. The many folds and creases of the robe seem to hold a small yet endless quantity of sand that gets everywhere.
While attuned to this robe, you are resistant to fire damage and have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks in sandy terrain.
The robe has 10 charges, it regains {@dice 1d10} charges daily at dawn. If you have spent the entire previous day wearing the robe in a hot desert, it regains an additional 2 charges at dawn.

You can expend up to 3 charges to cast one of the following spells (save DC 16) without providing material components: {@spell mold earth|xge}, {@spell gust|xge}, {@spell color spray|phb}, {@spell cloud of daggers|phb}, {@spell dust devil|xge}, {@spell gust of wind|phb}, {@spell leomund's tiny hut|phb} or {@spell wall of sand|xge}.

The number of charges expended is equal to the level the spell is cast at (no charges required for a cantrip). When cast in this way, each of these spells resembles sand or sandstone in someway. For example, {@spell cloud of daggers|phb} might be a flurry of floating sand and glass shards, while {@spell leomund's tiny hut|phb} might appear to have the color and texture of sandstone from the outside.

Additionally, when a creature with exposed eyes fails a saving throw against one of these spells, you can expend a charge and force them to become {@condition blinded} until the end of their next turn.

item.name: Robe of the Tundra
entries: This heavy white or grey robe can be worn with light or medium armor. The loose cloth around the shoulders can be formed into a simple hood and face mask, protecting the wearer from the elements. The many folds and creases of the robe seem to hold a small yet endless quantity of snow and resulting moisture. Frost and small iciciles may begin to form on the wearer's eyebrows and facial hair even in temperate climates.
While attuned to this robe, you are resistant to cold damage and have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks in snowy or icy terrain.

The robe has 10 charges, it regains {@dice 1d10} charges daily at dusk. If you have spent the entire previous day wearing the robe in a cold desert or tundra, it regains an additional 2 charges at dusk.

You can expend up to 3 charges to cast one of the following spells (save DC 16) without providing material components: {@spell frostbite|XGE}, {@spell gust|XGE}, {@spell armor of agathys|PHB}, {@spell frost fingers|IDRotF}, {@spell snilloc's snowball swarm|XGE}, {@spell gust of wind|PHB}, {@spell leomund's tiny hut|phb} or {@spell wind wall|PHB}.

The number of charges expended is equal to the level the spell is cast at (no charges required for a cantrip). When cast in this way, each of these spells resembles sand or sandstone in someway. For example, {@spell gust of wind|PHB} might be a small blizzard, while {@spell leomund's tiny hut|PHB} might appear like an igloo from the outside..
Additionally, when a creature fails a saving throw against one of these spells, you can expend a charge and force them to become {@condition slowed|J:General} until the end of their next turn.

item.name: Seed of Whispers
entries: This dark purple seed can hold whispers for later release. You can spend 1 minute to plant the seed in dirt or sand, water it and whisper a phrase to it that lasts 6 seconds or fewer. The seed begins to sprout and becomes a small tree or shrub {@dice 3d6*10|3d6 x 10} days later. Until the tree or shrub dies, whenever the wind blows through its leaves and branches, faint whispers can be heard on the wind, the whispers resemble the phrase you spoke to it during the planting.

item.name: Bag of Holding Grudges
entries: This bag has an interior space considerably larger than its outside dimensions, roughly 2 feet in diameter at the mouth and 4 feet deep. The bag can hold up to 500 pounds, not exceeding a volume of 64 cubic feet. The bag weighs 15 pounds, regardless of its contents. Retrieving an item from the bag requires an action.

If the bag is overloaded, pierced, or torn, it ruptures and is destroyed, and its contents are scattered in the Astral Plane. If the bag is turned inside out, its contents spill forth, unharmed, but the bag must be put right before it can be used again. Breathing creatures inside the bag can survive up to a number of minutes equal to 10 divided by the number of creatures (minimum 1 minute), after which time they begin to suffocate.

Placing a bag of holding inside an extradimensional space created by a {@item Heward's handy haversack}, {@item portable hole}, or similar item instantly destroys both items and opens a gate to the Astral Plane. The gate originates where the one item was placed inside the other. Any creature within 10 feet of the gate is sucked through it to a random location on the Astral Plane. The gate then closes. The gate is one-way only and can't be reopened.

entries.name: Curse
entries: The bag bears a curse and is extremely temperamental. If you offend the bag, it will seal itself shut, completely preventing access to the interior space, until you succeed on a DC 20 Charisma check to apologise to it. If you fail this check, you cannot attempt it again until the next dawn. Casting {@spell remove curse|phb} on the bag will end this effect early. The DM decides when the bag is offended, but typically putting poor quality or disgusting items inside it might offend it, as could removing high quality items. The DM might call for a {@dice d20} to be rolled whenever such items are added or removed from the bag, with a 1 resulting in the bag becoming offended.

item.name: Potion of Polymorph
entries: This blood-like liquid has transformative properties. When you drink this potion, you can cast the {@spell polymorph|phb} spell on yourself.

item.name: Tiefling Heart
entries: In many cultures, consuming humanoid flesh is deeply taboo. Yet, there are still those who do. Whether they acquire them through legal or illegal means, tiefling hearts are something of a delicacy for wealthy consumers.
When a creature consumes this fiery red heart, it takes 1 fire damage.

entries.name: Counterfeit Hearts
entries: Naturally the value of tiefling hearts, and the difficulty of acquiring genuine ones, leads some to attempt to make a quick profit by selling fake hearts. Sometimes hearts from pigs or other humanoids are infused with chilis or {@item alchemist's fire|phb} and sold as tiefling hearts.
These counterfeit hearts are actually worth around {@dice 2d4*5|2d4 x 5}gp, and a creature can determine its fake with a DC14 Wisdom (Medicine) check.

item.name: Lesser Otherform Mask (Aberation)
entries: Taking the form of a mask, helmet or cowl, this headwear can disguise your true nature. While wearing this item, you can use a bonus action to change your creature type to aberation until you use another bonus action to change back to your original type. While you are disguising your creature type in this way, you also have advantage on Charisma checks when interacting with other creatures of the same type. The effects end if you are no longer wearing the headwear.
At the DM's discretion, your appearance might also subtly change to fit your new type. For example, as an aberation, your skin may appear slimy and of a unusual hue.

At the DM's discretion, your appearance might also subtly change to fit your new type. For example, as a plant, your skin might take on a bark like texture or your hair might be replaced by leaves and vines.

item.name: Greater Otherform Mask
entries: Taking the form of a mask, helmet or cowl, this headwear can disguise your true nature. While wearing this headwear, you can use a bonus action to change your creature type to a different one of your choice until you use another bonus action to change to another type or back to your original type. While you are disguising your creature type in this way, you also have advantage on Charisma checks when interacting with other creatures of the same type. The effects end if you are no longer wearing the headwear.

At the DM's discretion, your appearance might also subtly change to fit your new type. For example, as a celestial, your eyes or hair might turn white or gold and even faintly glow. While, as an undead, you might appear more gaunt with dried skin and sparse hair.

item.name: Phoenix Feather
entries: This red and orange feather can be consumed in place of up to 300gp worth of material components when casting a spell that deals fire damage, creates light or brings a creature back to life, but not undeath.

item.name: Phoenix Eggshell
entries: This red and orange eggshell is always warm to to touch. Striking two fragments of the eggshell together creates a flurry of sparks, much like a flint and steel.

With at least half the eggshell intact, you can use it as a cup for beverages. Beverages that spend at least one minute in the eggshell become warm and slightly spiced, such as cider becoming mulled cider

item.name: Feathered Pauldrons
entries: While wearing these pauldrons, you have the {@condition lightened|J:General} condition.

item.name: Weighted Anklets
entries: WWhile wearing these metallic anklets, you have the {@condition weighted|J:General} condition.

item.name: Potion of the Lightweight
entries: When you drink this light, foamy potion, you become {@condition lightened|J:General} for one hour.

item.name: Potion of the Heavyweight
entries: When you drink this thick, metallic potion, you become {@condition weighted|J:General} for one hour.

item.name: Densweeties
entries: This tin box contains up to 12 sweets when found. {@dice 2d4+1} of the sweets are light and fluffy, the rest are hard and dense. When you eat one of the light sweets, you gain the {@condition lightened|J:General} condition. When you eat one of the hard sweets, you gain the {@condition weighted|J:General} condition. Either way, the condition lasts for 1 hour or until you eat another sweet from the tin.

item.name: Stink Bomb
entries: As an action, you can throw or drop this tiny vial at a point you can see within 20 feet. Any creatures that can smell within 20 feet of the point must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition distracted|J:General} for 1 hour. Whenever a distracted creature takes damage, they can repeat the saving throw, removing the condition early on a success.

item.name: Potion of Liquid Claws
entries: When you drink this metallic potion, or dip your hands in it, metal claws form on your fingers, which last for 1 hour before disintegrating. While you have these claws, your unarmed strikes are magical and deal slashing damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + your Strength modifier on a hit.

item.name: Potion of Greater Liquid Claws

item.name: Intangible Cloak
entries: This elegant cloak appears to be real, including physical interactions with the wearer's body and billowing in the wind, however, only the brooch is real. Other creatures and objects pass harmlessly through the cloak.
To discern that the cloak is illusory without touching it, a creature can use its action to inspect its appearance and must succeed on an DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check.

item.name: Fashionable Pipe Weed
entries: This self-replenishing weed can be used with a {@item pipe of smoke monsters|xge}. When you do so, the smoke monsters appear to have fancy hats and other fashionable accessories.

item.name: Scroll of Terrible Toe Curse
entries: When you read this scroll and speak the name of a creature you are familiar with that has toes, the scroll disintigrates into dust. From then on, whenever that creature stubs its toe, it hurts twice as much.

item.name: Switchblade
entries: This dagger is part of a pair (your DM decides if each dagger has a specific partner or can pair with any other switchblade).
If you possess only one switchblade, it does not require attunement and you have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

If you possess both switchblades, you can attune to them. The switchblades count as one item for the purposes of attunement. While attuned, the bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. In addition, you can summon one of the switchblades to your empty hand with a bonus action or as part of an attack you make with it.

Finally, these switchblades collectively have 5 charges, and regains {@dice 1d4+1} charges daily at dawn. When you hit a creature or object with an attack using one of these switchblades while holding the other one, you can spend a charge to swap spaces with the target. If the target is an object that Large or larger, you appear in the nearest unoccupied space to the target instead of swapping.

item.name: Little Book of Insults
entries: As an action, you can open this book to a random page and it'll magically provide the perfect insult for a target you can see within 30ft and that can hear and understand you. You then hurl the insult at the creature and it must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC 13) or take {@dice 2d6} psychic damage and become {@condition taunted|J:general} by you for 1 minute or until it is damaged by a creature other than you. On a successful save, a creature takes half damage and is not taunted.

item.name: Contraband Codex
entries: This thick tome appears fairly dull from the outside, however, on the inside several secret compartments have been cut into the pages. 20 pages within the book each magically open to a different compartment while the other pages appear ordinary. Each compartment can hold up to 10 lbs of material, not exceeding 6 inches in any dimension. The book contains an index page which describes the contents of each compartment in Thieves' Cant (or some other coded language decided by the DM). The ordinary pages might also contain coded messages, such as riddles or jokes at the expense of those fooled by the book.

When a creature who is unaware of the book's nature opens it, they can make a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check to randomly discover one of the compartments, otherwise they only see ordinary pages. The book's nature can also be discovered with an hour of study or with the {@spell identify|phb} spell.

Placing a contraband codex inside an extradimensional space created by a Heward's handy haversack, portable hole, or similar item instantly destroys both items and opens a gate to the Astral Plane. The gate originates where the one item was placed inside the other. Any creature within 10 feet of the gate is sucked through it to a random location on the Astral Plane. The gate then closes. The gate is one-way only and can't be reopened.

item.name: Portable Library
entries: This satchel contains an extradimensional space that can hold up 500 pounds of books, scrolls and similar documents. Documents stored inside the bag are perfectly preserved and do not fade, degrade or collect dust while inside. Once a document is placed inside, it vanishes into extradimensional space. The bag weighs 15 pounds, regardless of its contents.

As an action, you can reach your hand into the bag and describe the document you wish to retrieve, if such a document is stored in the bag, it appears in your hand as you pull it out the bag. You can be precise with your description, such as naming the title and author, or more vague, such as requesting the most recent document on a particular topic, the bag will do its best to accomodate your request in a way the DM sees fit. You can also request an itemised index of all the documents within the bag, though some information may be incomplete, such as damaged documents lacking titles or named authors.

If the bag is overloaded, pierced, or torn, it ruptures and is destroyed, and its contents are scattered in the Astral Plane. If the bag is turned inside out, its contents spill forth, unharmed, but the bag must be put right before it can be used again.

Placing a portable library inside an extradimensional space created by a bag of holding, heward's handy haversack, portable hole, or similar item instantly destroys both items and opens a gate to the Astral Plane. The gate originates where the one item was placed inside the other. Any creature within 10 feet of the gate is sucked through it to a random location on the Astral Plane. The gate then closes. The gate is one-way only and can't be reopened.

item.name: Memoria Stamp (1st Level)
entries: This ceramic or crystaline stamp resembles those used to produce wax seals, however, this one features arcane sigils rather than those of nobles or officials.

As part of an hour long ritual, which you can do during a short or long rest, you can use this stamp with a spell scroll of 1st level and permanently fuse it into your mind. Both the scroll and stamp are destroyed in the process. You must have the Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature and the spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, but the spell needn't be on any of your current spell lists.

Once the ritual is finished, you know the spell and can cast it with any spell slots you have of the appropriate level. The spell does not count against the number of spells you can prepare or know at one time. Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spell (choose when you finish this ritual).

item.name: Friend Flinger Fingers
entries: These metallic gauntlets feature tendon like structures stretching over the fingers to the wrist. When you use the {@action Throw|J:General} action to throw a willing creature, you can throw them up to twice as far.

In addition, this item has 3 charges, and regains {@dice 1d3} charges daily at dawn. When a willing creature is thrown, you can expend a charge to allow that creature to make a melee weapon attack as a reaction during or immediately after the movement. On a hit, the attack deals an additional {@dice 1d6} damage.

item.name: Gloves of Spoken Sign
entries: While wearing these cloth and wire gloves, you are proficient in Sign if you aren't already. In addition, when you communicate something via Sign, you can choose to have the gloves speak it aloud in a different language you know, even if you otherwise cannot speak it. This also works when communicating telepathically or with the message cantrip, the target hears the gloves speaking in the chosen language. Finally, you can replace the verbal components of spells with somatic ones.

entries.name: Gloves of Different Voices
entries: The basic version of this item leaves the details of the glove's voice up to the imagination of the players. If the DM wishes, they might specify that the gloves have a distinct pitch, tone, accent or dialect in their voice. They might also determine that each pair's voice is unique, and people may have to try multiple pairs if they want the perfect voice.

item.name: Belt of Blades
entries: This belt, which can be worn around the waist or as a baldric across the chest, features holsters and fastenings capable of holding up to six {@item dagger|phb|daggers}, {@item dart|phb|darts} or {@item sickle|phb|sickles}. While wearing the belt, these weapons can be drawn as a bonus action or as part of an attack you make with them, regardless of how many you draw in a turn. You can also stow a weapon in the belt as a bonus action.

Additionally, at the end of a short or long rest you can choose one of the weapons stored in this belt that requires attunement and attune to it. This attunement does not count against the maximum number of items you can attune to. This attunement ends if you attune to another weapon in this way or are more than 5 feet from the weapon or the belt for more than one hour.

item.name: Greater Belt of Blades
entries: This belt, which can be worn around the waist or as a baldric across the chest, features holsters and fastenings capable of holding up to six {@item dagger|phb|daggers}, {@item dart|phb|darts} or {@item sickle|phb|sickles}. While wearing the belt, these weapons can be drawn as a bonus action or as part of an attack you make with them, regardless of how many you draw in a turn. You can also stow a weapon in the belt as a bonus action.

Additionally, at the end of a short or long rest you can choose one of the weapons stored in this belt that requires attunement and attune to it. This attunement does not count against the maximum number of items you can attune to. This attunement ends if you attune to another weapon in this way or are more than 5 feet from the weapon or the belt for more than one hour.

Finally, the belt imbues the weapons stowed within it with a temporary magic. When you make an attack with a weapon you draw from the belt on the same turn, you have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls for the attack, unless the weapon is already a magic weapon with a bonus to these rolls. In addition, you can have the blade return to belt immediately after the attack, even if the attack was ranged.

item.name: Hidden Sheath
entries: This special sheath can hold one {@item dagger|phb}, {@item dart|phb} or {@item sickle|phb}. The weapon can be drawn as a bonus action or as part of an attack you make with it. The weapon can also be stowed as a bonus action.

Additionally, as a bonus action, you can conceal the sheath and the stowed weapon on your person. You can have the sheath and weapon can magically change appearance to suit the nature of the concealment. For example, you might conceal a dagger as a hairpin or a necklace.

While concealed, the physical shape of the sheath and stowed weapon can be altered to resemble the nature of the illusion, but only partially. They hold up to physical inspection on a passing glance, but not a thorough examination. For example, a character casually shaking your hand might not notice the sheath disguised as a ring, but a sentry closely inspecting the ring might notice its weight and balance is wrong. To discern that a disguised sheath and weapon are actually illusory, a creature can make a DC 15 Intelligence (investigation) check to determine its true nature. Any passive checks to see through the concealement have disadvantage.

item.name: Ring of Inescapability
entries: While wearing this ring, you have advantage on saving throws against being teleported against your will.

Additionally, when a creature you can see within 5 feet teleports more than 5 feet from you, you can use a reaction to either make a special opportunity attack against them or force them to make a DC 15 Charisma saving throw. On a fail, you are teleported with them, appearing in a unoccupied space within 5 feet of them. If the target teleports more than 60 feet, or into another plane, you cannot use this ring to teleport again until the next dawn.

item.name: Linen Armor
entries: This armor is constructed of tightly packed fabrics. Such armor comes in many forms, such as gambesons or linothorax.

item.name: Megaphone of Mutiny
entries: This metallic cone has 3 charges, and regains {@dice 1d4} charges daily at dawn. While holding it, you can expend 1 or more charges to cast the {@spell dominate horde|J:General} spell (save DC 13) from it. For 1 charge, you cast the 3rd-level version of the spell. You can increase the spell slot level by one for each additional charge you expend.

item.name: Monocle of Ridicule
entries: While wearing this monocle, it whispers secrets to you about a creature you are looking at. The secrets are minor and harmless, but may still be embarrassing or lead to mild mockery if spoken aloud. For example, you might learn that they mispronounce a particular word in an amusing way, that they once fell for an obvious scam or that they lost a fight with a child.

item.name: Sockpuppet of Spellspeaking
entries: This sock can be worn on your hand and used as a spellcasting focus. When you cast a spell with the sock, the verbal components of the spell must be spoken through the puppet. Any responses are also spoken by the puppet.

In addition, you can use this item to cast the {@spell message|phb}, {@spell vicious mockery|phb} or {@spell sending|phb} spell (DC 15). Once you cast the sending spell, you cannot do so again until the next dawn.

item.name: Leaf of Stupor
entries: When a creature consumes this leaf, they a relaxed state of mind. After 10 minutes of light activity, the creature gains the effects of the {@spell greater restoration|xphb} spell.
Additionally, the creature gains the effects of the {@spell modify memory|xphb} spell. They roll on the table below to determine the effects.

rows: A good memory is replaced by a negative memory.
A neutral memory is replaced by a negative memory.
A negative memory is replaced by a different negative memory.
A good memory is replaced by a neutral memory.
A neutral memory is replaced by a different neutral memory.
A negative memory is replaced by a neutral memory.
A good memmory is replaced by a different good memory.
A neutral memory is replaced by a good memory.
A good memory is replaced by a different good memory.
No memory is replaced but the character reflects upon an old memory and sees it from a new or enhanced positive perspective they didn't before.

entries: The DM determines the nature of the new memory. Most memories created by the leaf are strange and may defy logic, yet they seem real to the creature.

item.name: Dust of Swiftness
entries: When a creature consumes this white powder, it gains the effects of the {@spell haste|xphb} spell (no concentration required). The spell ends early if the creature is reduced to 0 hit points or targeted with the {@spell lesser restoration|xphb} or similar effect that removes the {@condition poisoned} condition. When the spell ends, the creature gains a level of {@condition exhaustion|xphb}.

item.name: Boots of Breeching
entries: While wearing these thick leather and metal boots you have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with unarmed strikes.

Additionally, you can use these boots to cast the {@spell knock|xphb} spell with a range of touch without expending a spell slot. Once the boots are used to cast the spell twice, it cannot be used to cast the spell again until the next dawn.

item.name: Wyll's Hat
entries: This elaborate hat makes you an enticing target for snipers. As a bonus action, you can choose a creature you can see within 60 feet that can see you and that is holding a ranged weapon. That creature must make a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition taunted|J:general} by you for one minute, or until another creature damages them. While taunted in this way, the creature also has disadvantage on melee attacks against you.
Once you use this bonus action twice, you cannot do so again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Curse
entries: This item is cursed. Attuning to it curses you until you are targeted by the {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic. While cursed, you cannot remove the hat. Ranged attacks deal an additional {@dice 1d4} damage against you. If a ranged attack is made as part of a creature's first turn in combat, it has advantage on the attack roll.

item.name: Knight Light
entries: This stone statue resembles a knight resting their hands on the pommel of their sword. When you speak the command word within 60 feet, the blade glows as if targeted with the {@spell light|xphb} spell, until a creature repeats the command word again. Multiple of this item can be activated or deactivated with the same command word.
This item comes in multiple sizes, ranging from a Tiny 6-inch tall variant up to a Huge 18-foot tall version. The DM decides what size you find.

item.name: Bag of Chattercrop Seeds
entries: This cloth bag of seeds has {@dice 1d4+2} seeds in it when found. As an action, you can plant a seed in dirt or sand. At the end of the current turn, a sentient fruit or vegetable appears in the space you planted the seed. The DM decides the type of crop that appears, such as a cabbage or marrow. It uses the {@creature awakened shrub} statblock, except it has a Charisma score of 16. You also determine the personality and additional trait of the crop by rolling a {@dice d4} on the table below. If the additional trait involves a spell, Charisma is the crop's spellcasting ability.

The crop is friendly to you and your companions, and it acts on your turn. You can use a bonus action to command how the crop moves and what action it takes on its next turn, or to give it general orders, such as to attack your enemies. In the absence of such orders, the crop acts defends itself and follows you, but takes no other actions. The crop vanishes at the next dawn or when it is reduced to 0 hit points.

rows: Calmer

The crop speaks in a slow, soothing voice. As an action, it can touch a willing creature and grant it {@dice 2d4+2} temporary hit points. In addition, the crop knows the {@spell calm emotions|XPHB} spell and can cast it once.
Challenger
The crop keeps screaming taunts and challenges at others, challenging them to duels. It knows the {@spell compelled duel|XPHB} spell and can cast it twice.
Chronicler

The crop constantly narrates the actions of its allies with grandeur. It knows the {@spell thaumaturgy|XPHB} cantrip. It can touch a willing creature and cast this cantrip as if that creature had cast it themselves.
Comical
The crop speaks in a jovial tone and frequently makes jokes and puns. It knows the {@spell tasha's hideous laughter|XPHB} spell and can cast it twice.
Curser
The crop speaks only in swears and insults. It knows the {@spell vicious mockery|XPHB} cantrip.
Cynical
The crop speaks in a pessimistic and brooding tone. It knows the {@spell sapping sting|EGW} cantrip and fills targets with a dour mood when casting it.

item.name: Woodwind Woodspeaker
entries: This wooden flute can be used to cast {@spell speak with plants} at will.

entries.name: Curse
entries: This item is cursed. When you cast the spell, the plants you speak to are aware the flute is made of wood and may react poorly, showing disgust, fear or even hatred towards you, though others may be indifferent at the DM's discretion.

If the plants are unfriendly to you, make a DC 10 Charisma (Nature) check. On a fail, the plants become agressively hostile to you, not only refusing to help you but hindering you in ways allowed by the spell for its duration, such as lying to you , placing difficult terrain in your path or clearing in front of your enemies. Additionally, any plant creatures within 300 feet become hostile to you and know your aproximate location for the duration as well. Each time a creature uses this item to cast the spell after the first, the DC increases by 5. The DC resets to 10 daily at dawn.

item.name: +1 Charm of the Hunter
entries: This charm can be worn on your person or attached to a weapon. You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with an attached weapon (provided it doesn't already give a bonus to such rolls), and you gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your ranger spells. In addition, you can use the charm or weapon as a spellcasting focus for your ranger spells.

When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points and that creature is under the effects of your {@spell Hunter's Mark|XPHB} spell (or is of a type associated with your Favored Enemy feature if you are using the Ranger from the 2014 Player's Handbook), you can gain temporary hit points equal to your level plus your Wisdom modifier. Once you use this feature you cannot do so again until the next dawn.

Once you use this feature you cannot do so again until the next dawn.

item.name: +1 Belt of the Scoundrel
entries: This specialised belt, bandolier or baldric hides many secrets. When you attune to this item, you can touch up to two weapons with which you are proficient, you might choose to holster these weapons in the belt itself. While wearing this belt, you have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with the chosen weapons (provided the weapon doesn't already grant a bonus to these rolls), and you have a +1 bonus to the DC of your Cunning Strikes.
When you use your Cunning Strikes feature, you can do so without reducing the damage of the attack. You can do so twice, regaining all expended uses each dawn.

entries: This specialised belt, bandolier or baldric hides many secrets. entries: This specialised belt, bandolier or baldric hides many secrets. While wearing this belt, you have a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with the chosen weapons (provided the weapon doesn't already grant a bonus to these rolls), and you have a +3 bonus to the DC of your Cunning Strikes.
When you use your Cunning Strikes feature, you can do so without reducing the damage of the attack. You can do so twice, regaining all expended uses each dawn.

item.name: +1 Idol of the Ravager
entries: When you attune to this idol, you can touch up to two weapons with which you are proficient. You may choose your Unarmed Strikes instead of a weapon. While wearing this idol, you have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls with the chosen weapons (provided the weapon doesn't already grant a bonus to these rolls).

When you would take damage or make a Strength saving throw, and you are not raging or incapacitated, you can immediately enter a Rage without consuming a use of the feature. You are treated as having entered the rage before the triggering damage or save. Once you do so, you cannot so again until the next dawn.

When you roll Initiative, you can regain an expended use of your Second Wind feature. You can use the feature immediately (no bonus action required) or expend the use on Tactical Mind on the Initiative roll. Once you use this feature, you cannot do so again until the next dawn.
