entries: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
When you attack with this weapon, you can use your Wisdom modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity modifier, for the attack and damage rolls.

inherits.reqAttune: by a creature with a charisma score of 13 or higher
entries: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
When you attack with this weapon, you can use your Charisma modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity modifier, for the attack and damage rolls.
You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Once per turn, when you hit a creature that is wearing medium or heavy armor with an attack using with this weapon, you can force that creature to make a Strength saving throw (DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + the ability modifer you used for the attack) or fall {@condition prone}.

variantrule.name: Hindering Traits
entries: Even the strongest heroes can have things that hold them back. These flaws have the opportunity make the character's story more interesting as they struggle to overcome challenges unique to them. The rules below are an optional way to encourage players to build flawed characters.
The Dungeon Master can decide to implement these rule in one of the following ways during character creation:

items: Each player is forced to take a number of Hindering traits at the begining of the game.
The players can freely choose or roll for a number of Hindering traits.
The DM can incentivize players to take Hindering traits by offering rewards for taking them. Examples of rewards could include ASI, Feats or Charms.

entries: The DM may also decide to assign certain traits to characters if they experience strong traumas that could lead to the trait developing.

entries.name: Hindering Trait Tables
entries: The DM may choose which of the below tables are available and their respective rewards, if any.

rows: {@b Weak.} Your Strength score is permanently reduced by 3 (to a minimum of 3).
{@b Clumsy.} Your Dexterity score is permanently reduced by 3 (to a minimum of 3).
{@b Glass Bones.} Your Constitution score is permanently reduced by 3 (to a minimum of 3).
{@b Absent Minded.} Your Intelligence score is permanently reduced by 3 (to a minimum of 3).
{@b Clueless.} Your Wisdom score is permanently reduced by 3 (to a minimum of 3).
{@b Weak Willed.} Your Charisma score is permanently reduced by 3 (to a minimum of 3).

{@b Inept.} Randomly choose a skill, or have the DM choose. You cannot have a modifier higher than 0 for this skill, regardless of proficiency or expertise, and you gain disadvantage on any rolls made with this skill.
{@b Short Sighted.} You have disadvantage on any Wisdom (Perception) checks and attack rolls against targets more than 30 feet away.
{@b Long Sighted.} You have disadvantage on any Wisdom (Perception) checks and attack rolls against targets less than 10 feet away.

{@b Phobia.} You have an irrational fear of a particular thing, such as dogs, darkness or large bodies of water. When you are confronted by this thing, you must succeed on a DC12 Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} by it until it is no longer visible.

{@b Infatuation.} You adore a particular type of creature or person, such as cute kittens or people with a specific hair colour. When you are confronted by a creature belonging to this group, you must make a DC12 Wisdom saving throw. On a fail, you become {@condition charmed} by the creature and wish to spend time with them, regardless of other any other pressing matters. This lasts for 1 hour or until you take damage.

{@b Vice.} You are addicted to a particular substance or activity, such as alcohol or gambling. Whenever you finish a long rest without having indulged in your vice since the last long rest, you must suceeded on a DC12 Charisma check or gain a level of exhaustion.
{@b Blind.} You permanently have the {@condition blinded} condition.
{@b Deaf.} You permanently have the {@condition deafened} condition.
{@b Mute.} You cannot speak.
{@b Illiterate.} You cannot read any languages without magic assistance, nor can you learn to.

{@b Missing or Paralyzed Leg.*} Your movement speeds (except flying), jumping distance and jumping height are all halved (rounded down). Additionally you have disadvantge on any checks or saving throws that require the use of your legs, such as climbing.*

{@b Missing or Paralyzed Arm.*} You only have one hand for items, weapons and spells. Additionally you have disadvantage on any checks or saving throws that require the use of arms or hands, such as climbing.*

entries: {@note *The DM may decide that your body also rejects any attempts to magically restore or replace the limb, including {@item prosthetic limb|tce|prosthetic limbs}.}

variantrule.name: Potions of Unknown Effect
entries: Alchemy is a complex science and few mortals can be expected to truly understand everything there is to know. Fortunately, knowing things is not always required to do things.

entries.name: Creating the Potion
entries: You can spend 1 hour using Alchemist's Supplies to attempt to create a potion. You must also provide some special component harvested from a creature of CR 1 or above, such as a giant scorpion stinger or a cyclops eye, creating the potion consumes this component. When you make the potion, make a Wisdom (Alchemist's Supplies) check and consult the table below to determine the result. Regardless of what you roll, you do not know the effect of the potion until it is consumed.

rows: Inert
You fail to make any drinkable liquid.
Lesser
The potion has one effect. Upon consumption, roll {@dice 2d100dh1|2d100}, take the lowest roll and consult the Potion Effects table below.
Basic
The potion has one effect. Upon consumption, roll {@dice 1d100} and consult the Potion Effects table below.
Greater
The potion has one effect. Upon consumption, {@dice 2d100dl1|2d100}, take the highest roll and consult the Potion Effects table below.
Superior
The potion has two effects. Upon consumption, roll {@dice 4d100dl2|4d100}, take the two highest rolls and consult the Potion Effects table below.
Coma
The drinker instantly drops to 0 hitpoints and falls {@condition unconscious}, they are automatically stabilised.
Greater Poison
The drinker takes {@dice 2d6+2} poison damage and gains the {@condition poisoned} condition for one minute.
Poison
The drinker takes {@dice 1d6+1} poison damage and gains the {@condition poisoned} condition for one minute.
Emetic
The drinker immediately vomits and is {@condition incapacitated} until the end of their next turn.
Sedative
The drinker gains a level of exhaustion.
Narcotic
The drinker falls {@condition unconscious} and cannot be revived by non-magical means for {@dice 1d4} minutes.
Laxative
The drinker feels a sudden urge to empty their bowels and has disadvantage on ability checks until they do so.
Diuretic
The drinker feels a sudden urge to empty their bladder and has disadvantage on ability checks until they do so.
Lubricant

The drinker's feet are unable to gain any traction. If the creature is standing on their feet at the end of each of their turns, they must make a DC14 Dexterity save or become {@condition prone}. This lasts for 1 minute.
Frostbite

The drinker takes {@dice 1d6} cold damage and all their fingers fall off. They are unable to perform any action that would require the use of fingers, such as making a weapon attack. Their fingers regrow after {@dice 2d4} minutes.
Clearwood
All wooden items become invisible to the drinker for 1 hour. They have disadvantage when using items or weapons made mostly of wood or when attacking creatures made of, or wearing, mostly wood.
Clearmetal
All metal items become invisible to the drinker for 1 hour. They have disadvantage when using items or weapons made mostly of metal or when attacking creatures made of, or wearing, mostly metal.
Mute
The drinker cannot speak in any language for 1 hour.
Hallucinogenic
The drinker is {@condition blinded} by shapes and colours only they can see for 1d4 minutes.
Gigglewater
The drinker is hit by the effects of {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|phb}. They automatically fail the save.
Identity Crisis

The first person the drinker sees, the drinker believes they are that person for {@dice 2d4} minutes. They believe the original person is trying to impersonate them and cannot be convinced otherwise until the effect wears off.
Aphrodisiac
The drinker is {@condition charmed} by the first creature they see after drinking for {@dice 1d4} hours.
Colour Change
The drinker's skin changes a random colour that is unnatural for their race. This lasts until the end of the next long rest.
Elder Hair
The drinker's hair turns a shocking white. This lasts until the end of the next long rest.
Hair Growth
The hair on the drinker's head grows by {@dice 1d4} inches, even if they didn't have any to begin with.
The Answer

The drinker has an epiphany and they suddenly understands the meaning of life, the universe and everything. They, and anyone they tell, suddenly forget it after {@dice 1d6} seconds, any attempts to write it down or record it are also destroyed.
Body Growth
The drinker's height permanently increases by {@dice 2d4} inches.
Body Shrink
The drinker's height permanently decreases by {@dice 2d4} inches.
Gullible
The drinker believes anything they are told by anyone they consider friendly for one minute.
Songbird
The drinker can only communicate through rhyme and song for one hour. This applies even to writing.
Anti-Aging
The drinker becomes younger by {@dice 2d4} years.
Aging
The drinker becomes older by {@dice 2d4} years.
Honesty
The drinker cannot knowingly lie for one hour, as if under the effects of the {@spell zone of truth|phb} spell.
Daydream
The drinker believes they are currently in a dream and nothing they see or hear is actually real for one minute.
Plant Speak
The drinker can sense the innermost thoughts and emotions of every plant within a 120ft radius for 10 minutes. They do not necessarily understand them.
Boney
The drinker can see their own skeleton for 10 minutes.
Fudge

The drinker realises they are in a game but no one believes them. They can choose to reroll a single check or save they make within 1 hour. The new roll must be made before the outcome of the first roll is known. After the hour, the drinker forgets all about the outer world as does anyone they told.
Handy
The drinker grows an extra arm and hand for 10 minutes, they are able to use this arm as a bonus action to take the {@action Attack} (one weapon attack only) or {@action Use an Object} action.
Polyglot
The drinker learns a new language chosen by the DM and can speak it fluently for {@dice 2d4} days, after which they completey forget it.
Pheremones
Any creature within 10ft of the drinker must make a Wisdom save against the drinker's Charisma or be {@condition charmed} by them for one hour.
Bestial
The drinker's nails grow long and sharp, their unarmed attacks become {@dice 1d10} + their Strength modifier slashing damage for one minute.
Polymorph
The drinker gains the effects of the {@spell Polymorph} spell for up to 1 hour, they are turned into a random beast of CR1 or lower. The DM decides the beast.
Dasher
The drinker's walking speed is increased by 15ft for one hour.
Thick Skin
The drinker gains +2 bonus to their AC for one minute.
Steroid
The drinker has advantage on all Strength checks and saves for one minute.
Stimulant
The drinker has advantage on all Dexterity checks and saves for one minute.
Booster
The drinker has advantage on all Constitution checks and saves for one minute.
Cognitive
The drinker has advantage on all Intelligence checks and saves for one minute.
Third Eye
The drinker has advantage on all Wisdom checks and saves for one minute.
Snake Oil
The drinker has advantage on all Charisma checks and saves for one minute.
Healing
The drinker restores {@dice 2d4+2} hitpoints.
Greater Healing
The drinker restores {@dice 4d4+4} hitpoints.
Energetic
The drinker instantly gains the benefits of a short rest.
Hyper-Energetic
The drinker instantly gains the benefits of a long rest.
Wild Magic
A Wild Magic Surge occurs, originating from the drinker.

variantrule.name: Pocket Sand
entries: Sometimes, you need to fight dirty. If your character has a free hand and quick access to a handful of sand or grit, such as with a {@item scholar's pack|phb} or being on sandy terrain, they can use it to gain a small advantage in combat.

As an action, the sand can be thrown at a creature within 5ft of you that has exposed eyes. The creature must make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or become {@condition blinded|phb} until the start of its next turn.

variantrule.name: Variant Fall Rules
entries: The rules presented in 5th Edition books for falling are intentionally simple, however, if falling is common occurance in your games, or you just want scenes of falling to be more dramatic and interesting, the following rules may be of interest to you.

entries.name: Variant Fall Speed
entries: The rules for falling speed prsented in both the Player's Handbook and Xanather's Guide to Everything have creatures falling so fast that it is generally impossible for the creature, or its allies, to do anything about it. Not only is this not very realistic, with creatures instantly moving hundreds of feet, it can feel underwhelming and anticlimatic. The rules presented here make it easier, though still extremely difficult, to act quickly and mitigate or even save a creature from falling to certain doom.

items: When a creature falls, they immediately fall 60 feet. If it is still falling on subsequent turns, it descends up to 500 feet at the end of each of its turns.

If a creature falls on its turn, it can attempt to use its remaining movement or actions duing the fall. If the creature did not fall intentionally, such as being pushed by a trap or another creature's reaction, the creature must fall at least 30 feet before it can do so, falling the remaining distance immediately afterwards if it is still falling.

entries.name: Optional Extra Rules
entries: The following additional rules may be useful, especially if falling is a frequent occurance in your game.

items: {@b Air Control.} A falling creature can use its walking or swimming speed to move horizontally as it falls. Moving 1 foot horizontally costs 2 feet of movement.

{@b Altered Gravity.} If a creature is falling in a location with gravity that is different to typical expectations, such as other planes or planets, the DM may wish to adjust falling rates accordingly. For example, a creature falling in a low gravity environment might only fall 30 feet on the first turn and then only 250 feet each subsequent turn. They might also simply fall 30 feet on every turn, never accelerating beyond that. If the falling rate is sufficiently changed, consider treating creatures as if they were one or more sizes larger or smaller, as per the Variant Fall Damage rules.

{@b Grab On.} At the DM's discretion, if a falling creature passes a suitable ledge, rope or handhold to slow or stop their fall, they can use a reaction to attempt to grab it. The creature makes a DC 15 Strength or Dexterity saving throw. On a success, the creature stops falling and takes half of the falling damage they would have at that point in their fall. The DM might decide that only player characters can make such heroic and difficult grabs, while most creatures simply fall.
{@b Sky Diver.} Once per turn, while falling, a creature can use an action to dive or slow their fall. They fall fall twice or half as far at the end of the current turn.

{@b Weightless Disorientation.} While falling, a creature is disorientated by the weightless feeling and has disadvantage on melee attacks, unless the attack deals piercing damage. A creature that has a flying or swimming speed or is acclimated to weightless environments, such as wildspace or the astral plane, might be immune to these effects.

entries.name: Variant Fall Damage
entries: The bigger they are, harder they fall. Many insects can survive falls from any height but humans risk injury after just a few feet, so why should they take the same amount damage from a fall. The table below takes creature size into account when taking fall damage. This table can also apply to falling objects if the DM chooses.

rows: Tiny
1 bludgeoning damage for every 10ft fallen (to a maximum of 20).
Small
{@dice 1d4} bludgeoning damage for every 10ft fallen (to a maximum of {@dice 20d4}).
Medium
{@dice 1d6} bludgeoning damage for every 10ft fallen (to a maximum of {@dice 20d6}).
Large
{@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage for every 10ft fallen (to a maximum of {@dice 20d8}).
Huge
{@dice 1d10} bludgeoning damage for every 10ft fallen (to a maximum of {@dice 20d10}).
Gargantuan
{@dice 1d12} bludgeoning damage for every 10ft fallen (to a maximum of {@dice 20d12}).

items: If you play with creature sizes smaller than Tiny, consider having these creatures take no fall damage whatsoever.

If you play with creature sizes larger than Gargantuan, consider having such creatures take an additional 1 damage for every 10 feet fallen for each size category above Gargantuan. For example, A creature 2 sizes larger than Gargantuan would take {@dice 1d12+2} damage for every 10 feet fallen (to a maximum of {@dice 20d12+40}).

variantrule.name: Auction
entries: The following rules are intended to be a simple and quick way to simulate an auction bidding while still allowing player the opportunity to participate and manipulate the results.
First, the DM determines a few details about each lot:

items: {@b The Lot} itself. This is something someone has put up for auction. This can be something a player character has put up for sale. Most auction houses will charge a fee or commission for each lot.
{@b The Appraised Value} of the lot. This value can be determined by the auction house itself or by other means prior to the auction.
{@b The Starting Bid}. This is where the bidding will begin and is typically 75% the Appraised Value.
{@b The Small Bid} amount. This is the minimum increase for each bid and is typically 5% the Appraised Value.
{@b The Large Bid} amount. This is a significant increase for an individual bid and may scare away rivals, it is typically 20% the Appraised Value.

{@b The Buyer's Pool}. The crowd of interested buyers is represented by a pool of d6s, typically between 3d6 for mild interest and 6d6 for considerable interest. The dice do not nesscessarily represent individual buyers but rather the crowd as a whole. The player characters may have opportunities to increase, or decrease, the pool by encouraging, or discouraging, interest among potential buyers prior to the bidding.

entries.name: Example: Ruby Necklace
entries: The party's cleric has chosen to put a ruby necklace they found up for auction. They have had the necklace appraised at 500gp. Therefor, the Starting Bid becomes 375gp, while the Small and Large Bid amounts become 25gp and 100gp respectively. The DM decides that the necklace is resonably attractive to the crowd, setting the Buyer's Pool at 4d6. They also decide that the bard's encouragement earlier boosted interest in the lot and increases the pool to 5d6.
Next, the bidding begins. Each round of bidding consists of one Bidding Roll followed by a round of Player Bids.

The DM makes a Bidding Roll. They roll the Buyer's Pool and, for each die, consults the table below for the effect. For the first Bidding Roll, assume a buyer has already made the Starting Bid, setting the current bid equal to it.

rows: No additional bid is made, and a die drops out.
No additional bid is made.
The current bid for the lot is increased by the Small Bid amount.
The current bid for the lot is increased by the Large Bid amount., and a die drops out.

entries: When a die drops out, it is removed from the Buyer's Pool for future Bidding Rolls, provided no die has already dropped out this round. Any effects the die had in the current or previous Bidding Rolls still apply.

Once the effects of the Bidding Roll are complete, then comes the Player Bets. Each player character in attendance can make their own bids. Typically auction houses will prohibit sellers from bidding on their own lots. Each bid must be equal or greater than the current bid + the Small Bid. If a bid is equal or greater than the current bid + the Large Bid amount, a die drops out. Once a player character makes a bid, then cannot do so again until after the next Bidding Roll.

Then the DM begins a new round of bidding, with another Bidding Roll followed by another round of Player Bets. This repeats until one of the following conditions is met, afterwhich the lot is sold at the current bid:

items: No dice remain in the Buyer's pool, a player character made the current bid and no other player character wishes to bid.
The Bidding Roll results in no increases to the current bid, a player character made the current bid and no other player character wishes to bid.
The DM is about to make a Bidding Roll with only one die in the pool, and the current bid was not made by a player character.

entries.name: Optional Rules
entries: At the DM's discretion, they can use the following additional rules:

items: {@b Eager Buyer.} If a buyer is especially wealthly, desperate or has been persuaded by the party to shaow particular interest, the DM might represent than by replacing a d6 with a d8. Typically no more than two d8s should be included in the Buyer's Pool.

{@b Reluctant Buyer.} If a buyer is poorer, disinterested or has been partially disuaded by the party, the DM might represent them by replacing a d6 with a d4. Typically no more than two d4s should be included the Buyer's Pool.

{@b Specific Buyers.} If it matters which buyer might get the item, the DM might wish to use different colored dice or roll in a specific order to have each die represent a specific NPC. Alternatively, the DM might simply decide the buyer most likely to make the highest bid.

{@b Discouraging Hike.} If the current bid is equal or higher than twice the Appraised Value, the DM might decide that any future 2s also result in a die dropping out. If the current bid is equal or higher than three times the Appriased Value, then a roll of a 3 might also result in a die dropping out.

{@b Encouraged Bid.} If a buyer is enchanted to make bids, the DM might replace a die in one or more Bidding Rolls with a 6. Such effects are often limited and might only work on a certain number of rolls, or cease to work once the current bid surpasses what the buyer can afford.
{@b Inspiring Bid.} When a Bidding Roll is made, a player character that bid since the Bidding Roll can use inspiration to reroll one of the dice.

{@b Reserve Price.} A seller may choose to place a minimum sale price on a lot. If the bidding ends and the current bid is not equal or greater than the reserve, then the item is not sold. An auction house will typically still request its fee or commision (based on reserve price) if the item is not sold.
{@b House Standard.} Some auction houses might place limits on the lots they will run. A common example might be refusing any lots without an Appraised Value above a certain threshold.
The current bid starts at 375gp, the Starting Bid.
The DM rolls 5d6 for the first Bidding Roll. They roll 6, 5, 5, 3, 1.
The 6 increases the current bid to 475gp and reduces the Buyer's Pool to 4d6.
The two 5s increase the current bid to 500gp and 525gp respectively.
The 3 has no effect on the current bid.
The 1 has no effect on the current bid, and would result in reducing the Buyer's Pool if the 6 hadn't already done that this round.
With the current bid at 525gp, the Player Bets round begins.
In an attempt to inflate the potential pay out, the rogue decides to make a bid of 550gp.
No other player characters bid and the DM moves on to the next round.
The DM makes an new Bidding Roll, this time rolling 4d6. They roll 5, 4, 2, 2.
The 5 and 4 increase the current bid to 575gp and 600gp.
The 2s have no effect on the current bid.
With the current bid at 600gp, another Player Bets round begins.
The rogue is impatient and decides to bid 700gp. This is equal to the current bid + the Large bid. The Buyer's Pool is reduced to 3d6.
With no other bids from player characters, the DM moves on the the next round.
The DM makes another Bidding Roll, rolling 3d6. They roll 4, 2, 1.
The 4 increases the current bid to 725gp.
The 2 has no effect on the current bid.
The 1 has no effect on the current bid and cause a die to drop out, reducing the Buyer's Pool to 2d6.
With the current bid at 725gp, the Player Bets round begins.
No player character's choose to bid, the DM moves on.
The DM makes another Bidding Roll, rolling 2d6. They roll 3, 1.
The 3 has no effect on the current bid.
The 1 has no effect on the current bid and cause a die to drop out, reducing the Buyer's Pool to 2d6.
With the current bid at 725gp, the Player Bets round begins.
No player character's choose to bid, the DM moves on.
The DM would make another Bidding Roll, however, they would only be rolling one die and the current bid was not made by a player character, the bidding ends.
The necklace is sold for 725gp and the cleric is very happy.

variantrule.name: Variant Mounting Multiple Riders
entries: Normally the maximum amount of creatures a mount can carry is based on weight. This can be tedious to track. Instead you can count it by size categories. Each creature has a Size Value based on its size; 1 (Tiny), 2 (Small), 4 (Medium), 8 (Large), 16 (Huge), 32 (Gargantuan). A mount can carry up to its own value in smaller creatures. Creatures grappled by the mount do not count towards this total. For example, a Large horse can carry up to 8, which could be 2 Medium creatures or could be 1 Medium and 2 Small or even 4 Small and so on.

If the mount is pulling a vehicle, such as a sled or cart, and that vehicle is moving smoothly over the terrain, creatures within that vehicle count for half their usual SIze Value. For example, 4 Medium creatures in a cart totals 8, allowing a single Large horse to pull them. If multiple creatures are pulling the same vehicle, they can add their Size Values together to determine the total amount they can carry. For example, eight Medium creatures on a wagon totals 16, allowing two Large horses to pull them.

At the DM's discretion the amount a mount can carry might be different based on a variety of factors. An especially strong Large mount might be able to pull 10 instead of 8. Meanwhile an injured or already laden Large mount might only be able to carry 4. An especially massive Gargantuan creature may be able to carry 64 rather than 32.

At the DM's discretion a mount can still carry over its limit though it expends 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves. If it is ever carrying more than twice its limit, its speed is reduced to 0.

variantrule.name: Death Alternatives for NPCs
entries: Hit Points do not always represent physical health, but rather a combination of physical health, stamina and willpower. You may wish to use the following rule to reinforce that idea.

entries.name: Falling to 0 Hit Points
entries: When a non-player character is reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, they can choose one of the options at the DM's discretion:

items.name: Give Up
entries: The creature simple falls {@condition unconscious} or dies as normal. Most weaker enemies will choose this option, only the more formidable enemies in a given encounter might choose the others.

items.name: Go Down Fighting
entries: The creature immediatly takes the one the following actions; {@action Attack} (one weapon attack only), {@action Cast a Spell} (cantrip only) or {@action Shove}. The creature then immediately falls {@condition unconscious} or dies.

items.name: Flee
entries: The character immediately moves up to half its movement. It must spend any subsequent turns fleeing from the scene until it believes it is safe for at least 10 minutes. While it is fleeing, opportunity attacks against the creature have advantage and if the creature takes any damage it immediately falls  {@condition unconscious} or dies.

items.name: Surrender
entries: The creature is {@condition incapacitated} but remains conscious and aware of its surroundings. Any subsequent damage to the creature results in it being knocked {@condition unconscious} or dying.

items.name: Blaze of Glory
entries: If the creature has Legendary Actions, Lair Action or Villain Actions, it uses one immediately. The creature then immediately dies, possibly as a result of the action it took.
When a creature uses one of these options and does not fall unconcious, they cannot restore hit points or take any hostile actions until they finish a short rest.

It is up to the DM which creatures choose which options. Many beasts, grunts and goons will simply Give Up or Flee upon being reduced to 0 hit points. Meanwhile, more determined enemies, including bosses, leaders and notable named characters might choose to Go Down Fighting or Surrender knowing they have more to offer than simply dying.

The DM might also decide that a creature close to 0 hit points takes one of these options at the end of their turn, effectively removing themselves from combat rather than waiting for someone to finish them off.

variantrule.name: Charms, Fears and Taunt Effects
entries: At the DM's discretion, when a creature is {@condition charmed|XPHB}, {@condition frightened|XPHB} or {@condition taunted|J:General}, and they wish to impose more specific flavor to the effect, they might have the creature roll on the associated table below. The result of the roll can be used to guide the DM or player in roleplaying the creature and the effects of the condition on their behaviour.

Using these effects may be unnecessary when the spell, feature or trait used to impose the condition already provides suitable flavor. The DM may decide to use the below effects instead, in order to distinguish the creature from others using similar means of imposing the conditions.

entries.caption: Charmed Effects
rows: You are a loyal pet, wanting to please the charmer and earn affection, and maybe treats.
Letting the world known your affection for the charmer is extremely important to you. Shout it from the rooftops!
The charmer is an old friend or flame of yours, you long for things to be the way they once were.
You've always been looking for new career opportunities, perhaps getting noticed by the charmer will be your big break.
There is a question or riddle in your head, and the charmer might be able to answer it for you.
You are really hungry or thirsty right now, the charmer can probably give you what you crave.
This is all just a fun prank or bit, you really don't want to be seen breaking character.
Just like the fairytales, everything will end happily ever after. If only the charmer could realise what you mean to each other.
The charmer will be far more useful to you as a willing ally than a dead or offended enemy.
You just learned the charmer is protected by a god or powerful figure, and you might incur their wrath if the charmer is harmed or upset.
Something about the charmer means the pair of you would make the perfect double act, you have to try and strike a deal with them.
The target just mentioned they have a very enticing business proposition for you, a layered scheme that will let you be your own boss.

entries.caption: Frightened Effects
rows: They know your deepest or most embarrassing secret and might let it slip at any moment if you aren't careful.
Oh no, they are so much more powerful than you thought. It might already be too late.
What's that under their cloak? Is it a volatile magic device that might kill you all with one wrong move?
You fear this person might be a specific person from your painful past. You are afraid to look, in case you are right.
It's a trap!
You are breaking a promise or law by being here. If they recognise you, they might rat you out.
There are so many snakes, spiders or other thing triggering a phobia you forgot you had.
They have archers hidden nearby, just waiting for you to get closer.
You'll be in real trouble if your boss sees you fighting them.
You just committed an embarrassing faux pas and need to avoid drawing more attention to yourself.
You think they have some horrible contagious disease or are carrying some lethal poison or allergen, you have to stay away.
You hear something coming...something dangerous.

entries.caption: Taunted Effects
rows: The taunter just called you or your friend something extremely offensive. You can't remember what it was, but they definitely said it.
The taunter is holding or wearing an item that is precious to you, they stole it!
The taunter won't stop laughing, and they are laughing at you.
You flash back to a time the taunter bullied or betrayed you.
All this horror is just an illusion, you just need to break the taunter's concentration.
Someone back home is deathly ill, and the taunter is selfishly hoarding the only cure.
Your whole life has been building to this moment, the taunter is the only thing left in your way.
The taunter just killed your dog.
To establish dominance, you need to take down the toughest guy here, and that's the taunter.
The taunter sold you some poor quality copper and was rude to your friend.
The taunter has just inadvertently set you up for the perfect trick shot, you can't not take the opportunity.
For years, the taunter has been annoying, humiliating and tormenting you. You've finally had enough.

variantrule.name: Negotiation
entries: {@note The following is adapted from Draw Steel by MCDM Productions.}

Sometimes, convincing a character to do something for the party can be a very impactful moment. Existing rules for roleplay and social checks can feel underwhelming for this purpose. Why should such important moments boil down to a single Charisma check? How should the DM decide if a character will go along with the suggesstion? How far should they go? And when does the character say enough is enough and refuse to hear any more arguments from the party? These rules intend to provide more nuance and guidance for those pivotal moments.

entries.name: When to use Negotiation
entries: Negotiations are meant for pivotal moments in adventures or story arcs. You do not need to run a negotiation for every merchant the party attempts to haggle with, or for every guard they try to bribe. You might use it however, to convince a character to join you on an important mission, to convince an official to pardon you rather than pressing charges or to convince an official to arrest a corrupt politician. The purpose of a negotiation is not to change a target's ideals, beliefs or character, but to persuade them that fufilling the party's request already aligns with who they are.

Negotiations can occur at any time, but it is the DM alone who determines when one is appropriate. The DM does not need to have them prepared ahead of time, but may wish to if they anticipate such a request from the party. Negotiations are unlikely to occur more than once a session and may even have multiple sessions between them.

entries.name: Negotiation in Combat
entries: Generally, if a character is actively fighting the party, they will not be open to negotiating, and the DM can simply decide that is the case. However, in rare cases, the party may be able to present something that catches the target character's attention and persuades them to briefly cease fighting and hear the party out. Such maneuveurs are extremely difficult and may require a hard check (DC 20 or higher), the influence of magic or some notable gesture, phrase or item relevent to the character.

entries.name: Interest and Patience
entries: The two primary statistics to track during a negotiation are Interest and Patience. Interest is a measure of how willing and invested the character is in fufilling the players' request. Pateince is a measure of how willing they are to listen to more attempts to sway them.

Examples of starting Interest and Patience based on the target's relationship to the players are included in the table below. These are guidelines only, the DM might decide to adjust any of the scores or DCs for any reason they see fit. A character that likes the party but is distracted by other worries might have little Patience but still have decent Interest and a low DC.

entries.caption: Starting Interest and Patience
rows: Hostile
The character despises the party, or their request, and is barely willing to listen.
Suspicious
The character is very doubtful or hesitant, but they will at least humor the party.
Neutral
The character is indifferent or indecisive, they might only be listening out of poiliteness.
Open
The character is willing to at least listen and willing to help, provided the party doesn't ask too much.
Friendly
The character would actively like to help the party and is willing to give them the benefit of the doubt.
Trusting
The character is very trusting of the party and believes they have their best interests at heart. It should be trival to sway them, if the party don't screw it up.

entries.name: Motivations and Pitfalls
entries: Motivations are things that drive and incentivise a character. Any difficult decision they make often becomes easier if it appeals to one of their motivations. A character while typically have 2 motivations. Common negotiations are included in the tables below.

Pitfalls are things that strongly dicourage a character. Things that offend, upset, or even frighten them. Bringing such ideas and memories to the table will only make things harder, regardless of how well argued they may be. A character will usually have 2 or more Pitfalls. Common Pitfalls are included in the tables below.

Note that all the below Motivations and Pitfalls are based upon the character's perception and situation, not nesscessarily the players's. A benevolent character might specifically want to help a group often considered evil, a justice motived character might believe in extreme, draconian priciples. Two characters that have the peace motivation might have very different ideas of what that peace means or requires. It may be as important to know what a motivation means specifically to a character, not just what it means generally.
The DM is not limited to the lists below, and be as specific or general as they wish with individual Motivations and Pitfalls for a character.

entries.caption: Motivations
rows: Benevolence
The character wants help others. These others could be a specific group or just people or creatures in general. Regardless, the character is motivated to do the best thing for these creatures.
Discovery
The character wishes to learn about something interesting to them. This could be a general thirst for knowledge and exploration or it could be more specific to a particular topic, field or question.
Freedom

The character is trapped or inhibited in some way, literally or figuratively. At least, they might feel like they are. They yearn for freedom and might desire the removal of some obstacle to this freedom, to have a lack of authority over them or avoid something that threatens to remove what freedom they have.
Greed
The character wants wealth or resources. This can simply mean money, or it can mean something more specifc or even abstract. Regardless, the character wants it, and lots of it.
Higher Authority

The character reveres, or desires, an authority figure above them. Be it a deity, monarch, leader, family elder, insitution or some mystical enitty the players don't understand, the character wishes to aid, honor or please this authority figure.
Justice
This character wants to see righteousness rewarded and wickedness punished. Whether this relates to a specifc injustice they wanted righted or a more general sense of right and wrong.
Legacy

The character wants to be known and remembered. They may wish to be seen as great or terrible or both. Alternatively, a character might wish to preserve or enhance the legacy of a faction or another character they admire or revile.
Peace
The character wants calm, either personally or more generally. They want things to be a certain way and to remain that way.
Power
The character seek influence over others. Whether through authority, status, magical abilities or many other means, they want to be the one calling the shots.
Protection
The character has something, someone or somewhere they wish to keep safe from harm and manipulation. It could be from specifc threats or from more general danger.
Revelry
The character just wants to have fun. They might enjoy parties, sports, food or other hedonistic indulgences. They want to be able to pursue these pleasures.
Vengeance
The character wants to bring harm or humiliation to someone that has hurt them.

entries.caption: Pitfalls
rows: Awkward
The character might become flustered and uncomfortable when others try flirting, fraternising, praising or otherwise attempting to charm them. They might seek to escape the conversation if so.
Cold
The character is not highly empathetic and is frankly insulted when others try to appeal to their so-called feelings or morals.
Ego
The character hates when others appear to be bragging. They may even be egotistical themselves and get competitive or petty when others are praised.
Loss
The character lost someone or something dear to them, literally or figuratively, They do not wish to be reminded of this, and might especially be offended if someone tries to exploit this grief.
Malevolence
The character wishes only pain on others, be it a specific person or group or just generally. Anything suggesting that fulfilling the request will benefit those they despise will sour the deal.
Pacifist

The character hates the idea of confrontation or harming others, even when inaction could lead to greater harm. Mentioning that the request could lead to harming people, physically or figuratively, will discourage the character. Often mentioning that inaction may lead to harm is still not enough to sway them either.
Principled

The character has strong priciples and is insulted by any attempt to suggest that they should, or already do, violate those priciples. These could be principles of right and wrong, of manners, dignity, pride, loyalty, integrity, taste and many others.
Rebellious

The character hates being told what to do or how to feel. If they believe someone is attempting to coerce them, especially by threatening them or invoking authority or duty, they may resist purely out of spite.
Shame

Something about the character or their past brings them great embarassment or shame. Maybe they can't so something they wish they could, did something they deeply regret or are the subject of scadalous rumors. Being reminded of this shame will hardly sway them, and may even lead them to reject the request out of fear of further shame.
Sheltered

The character does not like facing difficulty and hardship beyond their comfort zone. Mentions of potential dangers, leaving behind comforts, discovering new things or places, promises of new opportunities will all generally dissuade them.
Suspicious
The character is always wary of trickery and might be deeply suspicious of flattery or promising offers, even when genuine.
Worrysome

The character has something, someone or somewhere they do not wish to put in harm's way. A mention of this thing in any way that implies danger might distract them with worry or turn them off the idea.

entries.name: Deception, Threats and Torture as Pitfalls
entries: Deception, Threats of Violence and Torture are Pitfalls nearly all characters will posses, with few exceptions. Most people despise being lied to if they catch it, and directly hurting or threatening someone typically only paints you as the enemy to avoid, mislead or fight, not an ally to aid. The DM might treat such things as pitfalls, even if they are not among the character's designated pitfalls. A character's patience reaching 0 does not have to mean they directly say "No", rather it could mean they choose to lie, flee or remain silent instead of sincerly entertaining the Negotiation further.
Some characters, at the DM's discretion, might not harbor such tendencies and may be indifferent to, or even pleased with, such attempts.

entries.name: Learning Motivations and Pitfalls
entries: Negotiations are much easier once a player character knows at least some of the Motivations and Pitfalls of a character. It can be helpful and rewarding to provide opportunities for the party to learn one or more of them during or before the negotiation. This could be done in several ways:

items: Have the character make subtle allusions to their likes and dislikes during roleplay. Such as a greedy character frequently asking about payments or eyeing up valuable treasures.
Allowing Wisdom (Insight) checks to during roleplay, especially when a character is doing the above or when analysing a character's reaction to certain action or topics.

Allow the party to research the character during downtime or ask mutal friends and allies about them. This can include spells and features that reveal information, such as {@spell Commune|XPHB} or {@spell Legend Lore|XPHB}.

Spells and features that would normally reveal certain statistics about a creature, such as Know Your Enemy or Insightful Manipulator, might be used to instead reveal a Motivation or Pitfall at the DM's discretion.
Spells and features that can read minds, such as {@spell Detect Thoughts|XPHB}, might reveal a Motivation or Pitfall at the DM's discretion.

entries.name: Running a Negotiation
entries: Players should be aware that they are in a Negotiation and of how Negotiations work. They should also be made aware of the results of their arguments and the final outcome. It is up to the DM however, if they choose to reveal the current Interest and Patience during the negotiation. It can be a good way to help unfamiliar players understand the rules and their invovlement in a negotiation, but on the other hand, players may prefer a slightly more immersive experience of only being partially aware of how well they are doing.
Here's how negotiations will typically work:

items: The players make some great request of a character and the DM decides the stakes are sufficient enough for a negotiation.
The DM decides the character's starting Interest and Patience, as well as their Motivations and Pitfalls, if they haven't already.
The player characters will make arguments. They might take turns, contribute to the same argument or even let one character take the lead making multiple arguments in succession.

For each argument, the DM will determine If the argument succeeds (they may call for an ability check to decide this) and if it appeals to one of the character's Motivations or triggers one of their Pitfalls.

If the argument triggers a Pitfall, it fails, regardless of other factors. Both Interest and Patience are reduced by 1 and the character will usually make their distate known, warning or reprimanding the party.
If the argument fails and does not involve a Motivation or Pitfall, Interest is unchanged and Patience is reduced by 1
If the argument suceeds and does not involve a Motivation or Pitfall, Interest is increased by 1 and Patience is reduced by 1.
If the argument succeeds and appeals to a Motivation, Interest is increased by 1 and Patience is unchanged. Subsequent arguments cannot benefit form that Motivation again.

When Patience reaches 0 or the players decide to end Negotiation early, the character makes their final offer and cannot be argued with anymore. Compare their Interest to the Outcome table below to determine this final offer.

entries.name: Multiple Motivations
entries: Typically an argument will not appeal to multiple Motivations at once, but if the DM believes it does, they have a couple options:

items: Choose which Motivation the argument most appeals to and treat it as only appealing to that one, potentially allowing a subsequent arguement to still appeal to any others.
Treat the argument as appealing to all the Motivations, increasing Interest by 1 for each but also preventing subsequent arguments from appealing to any of them.

entries.name: Using Magic during Arguments
entries: Magic, such as the {@spell Charm Person|XPHB} or {@spell Friends|XPHB} spells, may be useful during Negotiations. The DM should consider carefully the effects of such magic. Remember the purpose of Negotiation is not to change a person's ideals, but rather to convince them the request already aligns with them. Therefore, while charming effects might make certain arguments easier, it will not change the target's Motivations or Pitfalls, nor force the target to ignore them. More powerful magic that potentially could change Motivations or Pitfalls has likely left the realm of Negotiation and entered the realm of domination.

When such enchantments end, if a character is aware magic was used to push them into agreeing something they otherwise would not have, they may be resentful and refuse to deliver on everything they promised, opting for a lower result or even refusing outright. However, this should be rare since, as mentioned above, subtler magics will not actively change the target's Motivations or Pitfalls, just make them more open to persuasion.

rows.name: No, and...
entries: The party do not get want they want. In addition, they gain some negative consequence.

items: The mercenary refuses to help the party and warns other mercenaries to not do business with the party.
The governer refuses to pardon the party and adds additional charges against them.
The guard captain refuses to arrest to corrupt politician and instead threatens to arrest the party for disturbing the peace.

rows.name: No...
entries: The party do not get what they want.

items: The mercenary refuses to help the party.
The governer refuses to pardon the party.
The guard captain refuses to arrest the corrupt poltician.

rows.name: No, but...
entries: The party do not get what they want, however, they may gain some lesser benefit.

items: The mercenary refuses to help the party but does offer to sell them a useful item, vehicle or piece of information.
The governer refuses to pardon the party but will reduce their sentence.
The guard captain refuses to arrest the corrupt politician but will assign a junior guard to invetigate them.

rows.name: Yes, but...
entries: The party get more or less what they want, however, there is an additional cost or consequence.

items: The mercenary agrees to help the party, but only if they get a larger share of the loot.
The governer will pardon the party but only if they surrender their weapons or testify against an ally.
The guard captain agrees to arrest the corrupt politician but only if the party can bring them solid evidence within 24 hours.

rows.name: Yes...
entries: The party get more or less what they want, if possible.

items: The mercenary agrees to help the party.
The governer agrees to pardon the party.
The guard captain agrees to arrest the corrupt politician.

rows.name: Yes, and...
entries: The party get more or less what they want, if possible. In addition, they gain additional benefits.

items: The mercenary agrees to help the party and even convinces a friend of theirs to help as well for no additional cost.
The governer agrees to pardon the party and orders someone to pay reparations to them.

The guard captain agrees to arrest the corrupt politician and also send officers to investigate their businesses and allies for further evidence against them. They may also offer the party some reward for the information they provide.
